div.p: THE ANTIPODES: A COMEDIE. Acted in the yeare 1638. by the Queenes Majesties Servants, at Salisbury Court in Fleet-street.
LONDON: Printed by I. Okes, for Francis Constable, and are to be sold at his shops in Kings-street at the signe of the Goat, and in Westminster-hall. 1640.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT Honourable WILLIAM Earle of Hertford, &c.
div.p:
THe long experience, I have had of your Honours favourable intentions towards me, hath compell'd me to this Presumption. But I hope your Goodnesse will be pleased to pardon what your Benignity was the cause of, viz. the errour of my Dedication. Had your Candor not encourag'd me, in this I had beene innocent: Yet (I beseech you) thinke not, I intend it any other, then your Recreation at your retirement from your
weighty Employments; and to be the Declaration of your gracious encouragements towards me, and the testimony of my Gratitude. If the publicke view of the world entertayn it with no lesse welcome, then that private one of the Stage already has given it, I shall be glad the World owes you the Thankes: If it meet with too severe Construction, I hope your Protection. What hazards soever it shall justle with, my desires are it may pleasure your Lordship in the perusall, which is the only ambition he is conscious of, who is

closer.signed: Your Honour's humbly devoted: Richard Brome.

div.head: To censuring Criticks, on the approved Comedy, The Antipodes.
div.l: IOnson's alive! the World admiring stands,
And to declare his welcome there, shake hands;
Apollo's Pensioners may wipe their eyes,
And stiflle their abortive Elegies:
Taylor his Goose-quill may abjure againe,
And to make Paper deare, scribling refraine;
For sure there's cause of neither. Ionson's ghost
Is not a Tenant i' the Elizian Coast:
But vext with too much scorne, at your dispraise,
Silently stole unto a grove of Bayes;
Therefore bewaile your errours, and entreat
He will returne, unto the former seat,
Whence he was often pleas'd, to feed your eare
With the choice dainties of his Theatre;
But I much feare, he'le not be easily wonne
To leave his Bower, where griefe, and he alone
Do spend their time, to see how vainly wee
Accept old toyes, for a new Comedie.
Therefore repaire to him, and praise each line
Of his Vulpone, Sejanus, Cateline.
But stay, and let me tell you, where he is,
He sojournes in his Brome's Antipodes.

lg.l: OPinion, which our Author cannot court,
(For the deare daintinesse of it) has, of late,
From the old way of Playes possest a Sort
Only to run to those, that carry state
In Scene magnificent and language high;
And Cloathes worth all the rest, except the Action.
And such are only good those Leaders cry;
And into that beleefe draw on a Faction,
That must despise all sportive, merry Wit,
Because some such great Play had none in it.
But it is knowne (peace to their Memories)
The Poets late sublimed from our Age,
Who best could understand, and best devise
Workes, that must ever live upon the Stage,
Did well approve, and lead this humble way,
Which we are bound to travaile in to night;
And, though it be not trac'd so well, as They
Discover'd it by true Phoebean light,
Pardon our just Ambition, yet that strive
To keep the weakest Branch o'th' Stage alive.
I meane the weakest in their great esteeme,
That count all slight, that's under us, or nigh;
And only those for worthy Subjects deeme,
Fetch'd, or reach'd at (at least) from farre, or high:
When low and home-bred Subjects have their use,
As well, as those, fetch'd from on high, or farre;
And 'tis as hard a labour for the Muse
To moove the Earth, as to dislodge a Starre.
See, yet, those glorious Playes; and let their sight
Your Admiration moove; these your Delight.

div.head: To the Author on his Comedy, The Antipodes.
div.l: STeer'd, by the hand of Fate, ore swelling Seas,
Me thought I landed on th' Antipodes;
Where I was straight a Stranger: For tis thus,
Their feet do tread against the tread of us.
My Scull mistooke: thy Book, being in my hand,
Hurried my Soule to th' Antipodian strand,
Where I did feast my Fancy, and mine Eyes
With such variety of Rarities,
That I perceive thy Muse frequents some shade,
Might be a Grove for a Pierian Maide.
Let Ideots prate; it boots not what they say.
Th' Antipodes to Wit and Learning may
Have ample Priv'ledge: For among that crew,
I know there's not a man can judge of You.

list.item: By-play, a conceited servant to Letoy.
Trulocke, a close friend to Letoy.
Followers of the Lord Letoyes, who are Actors in the By-play.

sp.l: TO me, and to the City, Sir, you are welcome,
And so are all about you: we have long
Suffer'd in want of such faire Company.
But now that Times calamity has given way
(Thankes to high Providence) to your kinder visits,
We are (like halfe pin'd wretches, that have lain
Long on the plankes of sorrow, strictly tyed
To a forc'd abstinence, from the sight of friends)
The sweetlier fild with joy.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Alas, I bring
Sorrow too much with me to fill one house,
In the sad number of my family.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Be comforted good Sir, my house, which now
You may be pleas'd to call your owne, is large
Enough to hold you all; and for your sorrowes,
You came to lose 'hem: And I hope the meanes
Is readily at hand: The Doctor's comming,
Who, as by Letters, I advertis'd you,
Is the most promising man to cure your Sonne,
The Kingdome yields; it will astonish you
To heare the mervailes he hath done in cures
Of such distracted ones, as is your sonne,
And not so much by bodily Physicke (no!
He sends few Recipes to th' Apothecaries)
As medicine of the minde, which he infuses
So skilfully, yet by familiar wayes,
That it begets both wonder and delight
In his observers, while the stupid patient
Finds health at unawares.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You speak well of him:
Yet I may feare, my sonnes long growne disease
Is such he hath not met with.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Then ile tell you Sir,
He cur'd a Country gentleman, that fell mad
For spending of his land before he sold it:
That is, 'twas sold to pay his debts: All went
That way, for a dead horse, as one would say,
He had not money left to buy his dinner,
Upon that whole-sale day. This was a cause,
Might make a gentleman mad you'll say; and him
It did, as mad as land lesse Squire could bee.
This Doctor by his art remov'd his madnesse,
And mingled so much wit among his braines,
That, by the over-flowing of it meerely,
He gets and spends five hundred pound a yeare now,
As merily as any Gentleman
In Darby-shire; I name no man. But this
Was pretty well you'll say.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: My sonne's disease
Growes not that way.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: There was a Lady mad,
I name no Lady: but starke mad she was,
As any in the Country, City, or almost
In Court could be.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: With study;
Tedious and painfull study: And for what
Now can you thinke?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: For painting, or new fashions.
I cannot thinke for the Philosophers stone.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: No, twas to finde a way to love her husband,
Because she did not, and her friends rebuk'd her.

sp.speaker: Ioy
sp.p: Was that so hard to find, if she desir'd it.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: She was seven years in search of it, & could not,
Though she consum'd his whole estate by it.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: No; he was not borne
With wit enough to loose, but mad was she
Untill this Doctor tooke her into cure,
And now she lies as lovingly on a flockebed
With her owne Knight, as she had done on downe,
With many others, but I name no parties,
Yet this was well you'l say.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Then sir, of Officers, and men of place,
Whose sences were so numm'd, they understood not
Bribes from dew fees, and fell on premunires,
He has cur'd diverse, that can now distinguish,
And know both when, and how to take, of both;
And grow most safely rich by't, tother day
He set the braines of an Attorney right,
That were quite topsie turvy overturn'd
In a pitch ore the Barre; so that (poore man)
For many Moones, he knew not whether he
Went on his heels or's head, till he was brought
To this rare Doctor, now he walkes again,
As upright in his calling, as the boldest
Amongst 'hem. This was well you'l say.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: And then for horne mad Citizens my neighbours,
He cures them by the dozens, and we live
As gently with our wives, as Rammes with Ewes.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: We doe you say, were you one of his Patients.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: 'Slid he has almost catch'd me; No Sir no,
I name no parties I, But wish you merry;
I straine to make you so, and could tell forty
Notable cures of his to passe the time
Untill he comes.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: But pray, has he the art
To cure a husbands Iealousie?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Mine sir he did: 'Sfoot I am catcht againe.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: But still you name no Party, pray how long,
Good master Blaze, has this so famous doctor
Whom you so well set out, beene a professor?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Never in publike: Nor indures the name
Of Doctor, though I call him so, but lives
With an odde Lord in towne, that lookes like no Lord,
My Doctor goes more like a Lord then he. Ex. Doctor.
O welcome sir, I sent mine owne wife for you:
Ha you brought her home againe?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: She's in your house,
With Gentlewomen, who seeme to lodge here.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Yes sir, this Gentlemans wife, and his sonnes wife:
They all ayle something, but his sonne (tis thought)
Is falling into madnesse, and is brought
Up by his carefull father to the towne here
To be your patient, speake with him about it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: How doe you finde him Sir? do's his disease
Take him by fits; or is it constantly,
And at all times the same?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: For the most part
It is onely inclining still to worse,
As he growes more in dayes; by all the best
Conjectures we have met with in the countrey,
Tis found a most deepe melancholy.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Was it borne with him? is it naturall,
Or accidentall? have you or his mother
Beene so at any time affected?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Never,
Not shee unto her grave; nor I, till then,
Knew what a sadnesse meant; though since, I have
In my sonnes sad condition, and some crosses
In my late marriage, which at further time
I may acquaint you with.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: the old man's jealous
Of his young wife; I finde him by the question
He put me to ere while.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Diverse yeares since; for we had hope a wife
Might have restrain'd his travelling thoughts, and so
Have beene a meanes to cure him; but it fail'd us.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: What has he in his younger yeares been most
Addicted to? what study? or what practise?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You have now, Sir, found the question, which I thinke
Will lead you to the ground of his distemper.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: That's the next way to the cure. Come quickely, quickly.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: In tender yeares he alwayes lov'd to read
Reports of travailes, and of voyages;
And when young boyes, like him, would tire themselves
With sports, and pastimes, and restore their spirits
Againe by meate and sleepe; he would whole dayes
And nights (sometimes by stealth) be on such bookes
As might convey his fancy round the world.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: When he grew up towards twenty,
His minde was all on fire to be abroad;
Nothing but travaile still was all his aime;
There was no voyage or forraine expedition
Be said to be in hand, but he made sute
To be made one in it His mother and
My selfe oppos'd him still in all, and strongly
Against his will, still held him in; and wonne
Him into marriage; hoping that would call
In his extravagant thoughts, but all prevail'd not,
Nor stayd him (though at home) from travailing
So farre beyond himselfe, that now too late,
I wish he had gone abroad to meet his fate.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Well sir, upon good termes Ile undertake
Your sonne: let's see him.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Yet there's more: his wife Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ile undertake her too. Is she mad too?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Alas the danger is they will have none,
He takes no joy in her; and she no comfort
In him: for though they have bin three yeeres wed,
They are yet ignorant of the marriage bed,

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I shall finde her the madder of the two then.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Indeed she's full of passion, which she utters
By the effects, as diversly, as severall
Objects reflect upon her wandring fancy,
Sometimes in extream weepings, and anon
In vehement laughter; now in sullen silence,
And presently in loudest exclamations.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Come let me see 'hem Sir, ile undertake
Her too: ha' you any more? how does your wife?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Ile undertake
Her too: and you your selfe Sir (by your favour,
And some few yellow spots, which I perceive
About your Temples) may require some Councell.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: But my sonne, my sonne sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: There's newes too much within,
For any home-bred Christian understanding.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes, pray Doctor Hughball
Play the Man-midwife, and deliver him
Of his huge Timpany of newes; of Monsters,
Pigmies, and Gyants, Apes, and Elephants,
Griffons, and Crocadiles; men upon women,
And women upon men; the strangest doings
As farre beyond all Christendome, as tis to't.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Beyond the Moone and Starres I think,
Or mount in Cornwall either.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: How prettily like a foole she talkes?
And she were not mine owne wife, I could be
So taken with her.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He talks much of the Kingdome of Cathaya,
Of one great Caan, and goodman Prester Iohn,
( What e're they be) and sayes that Caan's a Clowne
Vnto the Iohn he speaks of. And that Iohn
Dwels up almost at Paradice: But sure his mind
Is in a wildernesse: For there he sayes
Are Geese that have two heads a peece, and Hens
That beare more wooll upon their backs than sheep.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O Mandevile, lets to him Lead the way sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And men with heads like hounds.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You'll finde enough within I warrant yee. Ex. 3.
And here comes the poore mad gentlemans wife, Ent. Mar.
Almost as mad as he: she haunts me all
About the house to impart something to me:
Poore heart I gesse her griefe, and pitty her.
To keepe a Maiden-head three yeares after Marriage,
Vnder wed-locke and key, insufferable! monstrous,
It turnes into a wolfe within the flesh,
Not to be fed with Chickens, and tame Pigeons.
J could wish maids be warn'd by't, not to marry
Before they have wit to lose their Maiden-heads,
For feare they match with men whose wits are past it.
What a sad looke, and what a sigh was there?
Sweet Mistris Ioylesse, how is't with you now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: When J shall know Ile tell, pray tell me first,
How long have you beene married?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Now she is on it. Three yeares forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And truely so have J, we shall agree J see.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No woman merrier, now J have met with one
Of my condition. Three yeares married say you, ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Three yeares married, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tis just my story. And you have had no child,
That's still my story, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Nay I have had two children.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Are you sure on't,
Or does your husband onely tell you so,
Take heed o'that, for husbands are deceitfull.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: But I am o'the surer side, I am sure
I groan'd for mine and bore 'hem. when at best,
He but beleeves he got 'hem.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yet both he
And you may be deceiv'd, for now Ile tell you,
My husband told me, fac'd me downe and stood on't,
We had three sonnes, and all great travellers,
That one had shooke the great Turke by the beard,
I never saw 'hem, nor am I such a foole
To thinke that children can be got and borne,
Train'd up to men, and then sent out to travell,
And the poore mother never know nor feele
Any such matter; there's a dreame indeede.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now you speake reason, and tis nothing but
Your husbands madnesse that would put that dreame
Into you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He may put dreames into me, but
He nere put child nor any thing towards it yet
To me to making: something sure belongs weepe.
To such a worke for I am past a child
My selfe to think they are found in parsley beds,
Strawberry banks or Rosemary bushes, though
I must confesse I have sought and search'd such places,
Because I would faine have had one.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray tell me, for I thinke no body heares us,
How came you by your babes? I cannot thinke
Your husband got them you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Foole did I say?
She is a witch I thinke: why not my husband,
Pray can you charge me with another man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor with him neither, be not angry pray now.
For were I now to dye, I cannot guesse
What a man do's in child-getting, I remember
A wanton mayd once lay with me, and kiss'd
And clip't, and clapt me strangely, and then wish'd
That I had beene a man to have got her with childe:
What must I then ha' done, or (good now tell me)
What has your husband done to you?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Was ever
Such a poore peece of innocence, three yeeres married?
Does not your husband use to lye with you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes he do's use to lye with me, but he do's not
Lye with me to use me as she should I feare,
Nor doe I know to teach him, will you tell me,
Ile lye with you and practise if you please.
Pray take me for a night or two: or take
My husband and instruct him, But one night,
Our countrey folkes will say, you London wives
Doe not lye every night with your owne husbands.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your countrey folkes should have done well to ha' sent
Some newes by you, but I trust none told you there,
We use to leave our fooles to lye with mad-men.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No not I
But rather pitty your simplicity.
Come Ile take charge and care of you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And wage my skill, against my doctors art,
Sooner to ease you of these dangerous fits,
Then he shall rectifie your husbands wits. Ex.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Why broughtst thou not mine Armes, and Pedegree
Home with thee Blaze, mine honest Heralds, Painter?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I have not yet my Lord, but all's in readinesse,
According to the Heralds full directions.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: But has he gone to the root, has he deriv'd me,
Ex origine, ab antiquo? has he fetch'd me
Farre enough Blaze?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Full foure descents beyond
The conquest my good Lord, and findes that one
Of your French ancestry came in with the conqueror.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Iefrey Letoy, twas he, from whom the English
Letoy's have our descent; and here have tooke
Such footing, that we'll never out while France
Is France, and England England,
And the Sea passable to transport a fashion.
My ancestors and I have beene beginners
Of all new fashions in the Court of England
From before Primo Ricardi Secundi
Untill this day.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I cannot thinke my Lord
They'll follow you in this though.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Marke the end,
I am without a precedent for my humour.
But is it spread, and talk'd of in the towne?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: It is my Lord, and laught at by a many.
I am more beholding to them, then all the rest:
Their laughter makes me merry; others mirth,
And not mine owne it is, that feeds me that
Battens me as poore mens cost do's Usurers.
But tell me Blaze, what say they of me, ha?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: They say my Lord you looke more like a pedlar,
Then like a Lord, and live more like an Emperor.

sp.speaker: Let
sp.l: Why there they ha' me right, let others shine
Abroad in cloth o' bodkin, my broad cloath,
Pleases mine eye as well, my body better,
Besides I'm sure tis paid for (to their envy)
I buy with ready money: and at home here
With as good meat, as much magnificence,
As costly pleasures, and as rare delights,
Can satisfie my appetite and senses,
As they with all their publique shewes, and braveries.
They runne at ring, and tilt 'gainst one another,
I and my men can play a match at football,
Wrastle a hansome fall, and pitch the barre,
And crack the cudgells, and a pate sometimes,
Twould doe you good to see't.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: They hunt the Deere, the Hare, the Fox, the Otter,
Polcates, or Harlots, what they please, whilst I
And my mad Grigs, my men can runne at base,
And breath our selves at Barly-breake, and dancing.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes my Lord i'th countrey when you are there.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And now I am here i'th city, Sir, I hope
I please my selfe with more choyse home delights,
Then most men of my ranke.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I know my Lord
Your house in substance is an Amphitheater
Of exercise and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Sir, I have
For exercises, Fencing, Dancing, Vaulting,
And for delight, Musique of all best kindes:
Stage-playes, and Masques, are nightly my pastimes.
And all within my selfe. My owne men are
My Musique, and my Actors. J keepe not
A man or boy but is of quality:
The worst can sing or play his part o'th' Violls,
And act his part too in a Comedy,
For which I lay my bravery on their backs;
And where another Lord undoes his followers,
J maintaine mine like Lords. And there's my bravery.
sp.stage: Hoboyes. A service as for dinner, passe over the Stage, borne by many Servitors richly apparreld, doing honor to Letoy as they passe. Ex.
sp.l: Now tell me Blaze, looke these like Pedlers men?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I tell thee,
These lads can act the Emperors lives all over,
And Shakespeares Chronicled histories, to boot,
And were that Caesar, or that English Earle,
That lov'd a Play and Player so well now living,
I would not be out-vyed in my delights.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I love the quality of Playing I, J love a Play with all
My heart, a good one; and a Player that is
A good one too, with all my heart: As for the Poets,
No men love them, I thinke, and therefore
I write all my playes my selfe, and make no doubt
Some of the Court will follow
Me in that too. Let my fine Lords
Talke o' their Horse-tricks, and their Jockies, that
Can out-talke them. Let the Gallants boast
Their May-games, Play-games, and their Mistresses,
I love a Play in my plaine cloaths, I,
And laugh upon the Actors in their brave ones. Ent. Quailp.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.p: My Lord, your dinner stayes prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Well, well,
Be you as ready with your grace as I Ex. Quail.
Am for my meate, and all is well. Blaze we have rambled
From the maine poynt this while, it seems by his letter,
My Doctor's busie at thy house. I know who's there,
Beside, give him this Ring, Tell him it wants
A finger: farewell good Blaze.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Tell him it wants a finger! My small wit,
Already finds what finger it must fit.

div.head: Act. 1. Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter Doctor, Peregrine, a Booke in his hand, Ioylesse, Diana

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sir I applaud your noble disposition,
And even adore the spirit of Travaile in you,
And purpose to waite on it through the world,
In which I shall but tread againe the steps
I heretofore have gone.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: All the world o're ha' you bin already?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Yes, through, and through:
No Isle nor Angle in that Neather world,
But I have made discovery of: Pray sir sit;
And sir be you attentive, I will warrant
His speedy cure without the helpe of Gallen,
Hippocrates, Avicen, or Dioscorides,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: A rare man: Husband, truely I like his person
As well as his rare skill.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Into your chamber.
I doe not like your liking of mens persons.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Nay Lady you may stay: Heare and admire,
If you so please: But make no interruptions.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: And let no looser words, or wandring looke
Bewray an intimation of the slight
Regard you beare your husband, lest I send you
Upon a further pilgrimage, than he
Feignes to convay my sonne.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Doe you thinke sir, to th' Antipodes such a journey?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I thinke there's none beyond it; and that Mandevile
Whose excellent worke this is, was th' onely man
That e're came neare it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Beyond all English legges that I can read of.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What thinke you sir of Drake, our famous Countriman?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Drake was a Dy'dapper to Mandevile,
Candish, and Hawkins, Furbisher, all our voyagers
Went short of Mandevile: But had he reach'd
To this place here— yes here— this wildernesse,
And seene the trees of the Sunne and Moone, that speake,
And told King Alexander of his death, he then
Had left a passage ope for Travailers:
That now is kept and guarded by wild beasts,
Dragons, and Serpents, Elephants white and blue
Vnicornes, and Lyons of many colours,
And monsters more, as numberlesse, as namelesse.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Stay there,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Read here else: can you read?
Is it not true?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No truer than I ha' seen't.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Ha' you bin there Sir, ha' you seene those trees?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And talk'd with 'hem, and tasted of their fruit.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Read here againe then: it is written here,
That you may live foure or five hundred yeere.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Brought you none of that fruit home with you sir?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You would have some of't would you, to have hope
T'out-live your husband by't.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Y'd ha't for you,
In hope you might out-live your jealousie.

sp.speaker: Doct
sp.l: Your patience both I pray; I know the griefe
You both doe labour with, and how to cure it.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Would I had given you halfe my land 'twere done.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Would I had given him halfe my love, to settle
The tother halfe free from incumbrances
Upon my husband.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Doe not thinke it strange sir:
Ile make your eyes witnesses of more
Than J relate, if you'll but travaile with me.
You heare me not deny that all is true
That Mandevile delivers of his Travailes,
Yet J my selfe may be as well beleev'd.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Since you speake reverently of him, say on.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Of Europe ile not speak, tis too neare home:
Who's not familiar with the Spanish garbe,
Th'Jtalian shrug, French cringe, and German hugge?
Nor will J trouble you with my observations
Fetcht from Arabia, Paphlagonia,
Mesopotamia, Mauritania,
Syria, Thessalia, Persia, India,
All still is too neare home: though I have touch'd
The Clouds upon the Pyrenaean mountaines,
And bin on Paphos isle, where I have kist
The image of bright Venus: All is still
Too neare home to be boasted.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That I like well in him too, he will not boast of kissing
A woman too neare home.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: These things in me are poore: they found
In a farre travellers care,
Like the reports of those, that beggingly
Have put out, on returnes from Edenburgh,
Paris, or Venice, or perhaps Madrid,
Whither a Millaner may with halfe a nose
Smell out his way: And is not neare so difficult,
As for some man in debt, and unprotected
To walke from Charing-crosse to th'old Exchange.
No, J will pitch no nearer than th' Antipodes;
That which is farthest distant, foot to foote
Against our Region.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: What with their heeles upwards?
Blesse us! how scape they breaking o' their necks?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: they walke upon firme earth, as we doe here,
And have the Firmament over their heads,
As we have here

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And yet just under us!
Where is hell then? if they whose feet are towards us,
At the lower part of the world have heaven too
Beyond their heads, where's hell?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You may finde that
Without inquiry: Cease your idle questions.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Sure Hell's above ground then in jealous husbands.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What people sir (J pray proceed) what people
Are they of the Antipodes? are they not such
As Mandevile writes of, without heads or necks,
Having their eyes plac'd on their shoulders, and
Their mouths amidst their breasts?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Though heeles goe upwards, and their feet should slip,
They have no necks to breake.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Silence sweete Lady.
Pray give the gentleman leave to understand me.
The people through the whole world of Antipodes,
In outward feature, language, and religion,
Resemble those to whom they are supposite:
They under Spaine appeare like Spaniards,
Vnder France French-men, under England English
To the exterior shew: but in their manners,
Their carriage, and condition of life
Extreamly contrary. To come close to you,
What part o' th' world's Antipodes shall J now
Decipher to you, or would you travaile to?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: That is th' Antipodes of England.
The people there are contrary to us.
As thus; here (heaven be prais'd) the Magistrates
Governe the people: there the people rule
The Magistrates.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: There's pretious bribing then.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You'l hold your peace,

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Nay Lady tis by Nature,
Here generally men governe the women.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: But there the women over-rule the men,
If some men faile here in their power, some women
Slip their holds there. As parents here, and masters,
Command, there they obey the childe and servant.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: But pray Sir, is't by nature or by art,
That wives oresway their husbands there?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Then art's above nature, as they are under us.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: In briefe Sir, all
Degrees of people both in sex, and quality,
Deport themselves in life and conversation,
Quite contrary to us.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why then the women
Doe get the men with child: and put the poore fooles
To grievous paine I warrant you in bearing.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Into your Chamber, get you in I charge you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: By no meanes, as you tender your sonnes good.
No Lady no; that were to make men women,
And women men. But there the maids doe woe
The Batchelors, and tis most probable,
The wives lye uppermost.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That is a trim
Upside-downe Antipodian tricke indeed.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: And then at christenings and gossips feasts,
A woman is not seene, the men doe all
The tittle-tattle duties, while the women
Hunt, Hawke, and take their pleasure.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ha' they good game I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Excellent,
But by the contraries to ours, for where
We Hawke at Pheasant, Partrich, Mallard, Heron,
With Goshawke, Tarsell, Falcon, Laneret;
Our Hawks, become their game, our game their Hawks,
And so the like in hunting. There the Deere
Pursue the Hounds, and (which you may thinke strange)
I ha' seene one Sheepe worry a dozen Foxes,
By Moone-shine; in a morning before day,
They hunt, trayne-sents with Oxen, and plow with Dogges.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Are not their Swannes all blacke, and Ravens white?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Yes indeed are they; and their Parrets teach
Their Mistresses to talke.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: They keepe their Cats in cages,
From Mice that would devoure them else; and birds
Teach 'hem to whistle, and cry beware the Rats Pusse.
But these are frivolous nothings. I have knowne
Great Ladyes ride great horses run at tilt;
At Ring, Races, and hunting matches, while
Their Lords at home have painted, pawned their Plate
And Jewels to feast their honourable servants.
And there the Merchants wives doe deale abroad
Beyond seas, while their husbands cuckold them
At home.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Then there are cuckolds too it seemes,
As well as here.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: By hearesay Sir. I am not wise enough
To speake it on my knowledge yet.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Patience good Sir,

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: What do you laugh, that there is cuckold-making
In the Antipodes, I tell you Sir,
It is not so abhorr'd here as tis held
In reputation there: all your old men
Doe mary girles, and old women boyes,
As generation were to be maintain'd
Onely by cuckold making.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Pray your Patience.
There's no such honest men there in their world,
As are their Lawyers: they give away
Their practise; and t'enable 'hem to doe so,
Being all handy-crafts, or Labouring men,
They work (poore hearts full hard) in the vacations,
To give their law for nothing in the terme times.
No fees are taken: Which makes their divines,
Being generally covetous, the greatest wranglers
In Law sutes of a kingdome, you have not there
A gentleman in debt, though citizens
Haunt them with cap in hand to take their wares.
On credit.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: What fine sport would that be here now!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: All wit and mirth and good society
Is there among the hirelings, clownes, and tradesmen,
And all their Poets are Puritanes.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: And players too. But they are all the sobrest
Precisest people pickt out of a nation.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: She must if you can hope for any cure,
Be govern'd Sir: your jealousie will grow
A worse disease then your sonnes madnesse else,
You are content I take the course I told you of
To cure the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Say Master Perigrine, will you travaile now
With mee to the Antipodes, or has not
The journey wearied you in the description.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No I could heare you a whole fortnight, but A Bowle on the table.
Let's loose no time, pray talke on as we passe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: First, Sir a health to auspicate our travailes,
And wee'll away.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Gi' mee't. What's he? One sent

div.head: Act. 1. Scene. 7.
div.l: I feare from my dead mother, to make stop
Of our intended voyage.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: My Lord, Sir understands the course y'are in,
By your letters he tells mee; and bad me gi' you
This Ring, which wants a finger here he sayes

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: No Sir, he brings me word
The Marriner calls away; the winde and tyde
Are faire, and they are ready to weigh anchor,
Hoyst sayles, and onely stay for us, pray drinke Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A health then to the willing winds and seas,
And all that steere towards th' Antipodes.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: He has not drunke so deepe a draught this twelvmonth.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Tis a deepe draught indeed, and now tis downe,
And carries him downe to the Antipodes?
I meane but in a dreame.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Alasse I feare.
See he beginnes to sink.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Trust to my skill,
Pray take an arme, and see him in his cabbin.
Good Lady save my Ring that's fallen there.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: In sooth a mervailous neate and costly one

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: So, so, the Ring has found a finger.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Come sir, aboord, aboord, aboord, aboord.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: To bed, to bed, to bed: I know your voyage,
And my deare Lords deare plot, I understand,
Whose Ring hath past here by your flight of hand.
TO night saiest thou my Hughball?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: By all meanes,
And if your Play takes to my expectation,
As I not doubt my potion workes to yours,
Your fancy and my cure shall be cry'd up
Miraculous. O y'are the Lord of fancy.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I'm not ambitious of that title Sir,
No, the Letoy's are of Antiquity,
Ages before the fancyes were begot,
And shall beget still new to the worlds end.
But are you confident o' your potion doctor?
Sleeps the young man?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Yes, and has slept these twelve houres,
After a thousand mile an houre out-right,
By sea and land; and shall awake anone
In the Antipodes.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Well Sir my Actors
Are all in readinesse; and I thinke all perfect,
But one, that never will be perfect in a thing
He studies; yet he makes such shifts extempore,
(Knowing the purpose what he is to speak to)
That he moves mirth in me 'bove all the rest.
For I am none of those Poeticke furies,
That threats the Actors life, in a whole play,
That addes a sillable, or takes away.
If he can frible through, and move delight
In others, I am pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: It is that mimick fellow which your Lordship
But lately entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: He will be wondrous apt in my affaire:
For I must take occasion to interchange,
Discourse with him sometimes amidst their Scenes,
T'informe my patient, my mad young travellor
In diverse matters.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Doe, put him to't: I use't my selfe sometimes.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I know it is your way.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Well to the businesse.
Hast wrought the jealous Gentleman, old Ioylesse,
To suffer his wife to see our Comedy.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: She brings your Ring, my Lord, upon her finger,
And he brings her in's hand. I have instructed her
To spurre his jealousie of o'the legges.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: And I will helpe her in't.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: the young distracted
Gentlewoman too, that's sicke of her virginity,
Yet knowes not what it is; and Blaze and's wife
Shall all be your guests to night, and not alone
Spectators, but (as we will carry it) Actor
To fill your Comicke Scenes with double mirth.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Go fetch 'hem then, while I prepare my Actors. Ex. Doc.
Within there hoe?
sp.stage:
Within.
1 This is my beard and haire.
2 My Lord appointed it for my part.
3 No, this is for you; and this is yours, this grey one.
4 Where be the foyles, and Targets for the women?
1 Here, can't you see?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: What a rude coyle is there? But yet it pleases me.
sp.stage:
Within.
1 You must not weare that Cloak and Hat.
2 Who told you so? I must.
sp.l: In my first Scene, and you must weare that robe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: What a noyse make those knaves? come in one of you:
Are you the first that answers to that name?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Why are not you ready yet?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I am not to put on my shape, before
I have spoke the Prologue. And for that my Lord
I yet want something.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: What I pray with your grave formality?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I want my Beaver-shooes, and Leather-Cap,
To speake the Prologue in; which were appoynted
By your Lordships owne direction.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Well sir, well:
There they be for you; I must looke to all.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Certes my Lord, it is a most apt conceit:
The Comedy being the world turn'd upside-downe,
That the presenter weare the Capitall Beaver
Upon his feet, and on his head shooe-leather.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Trouble not you your head with my conceite,
But minde your part Let me not see you act now,
In your Scholasticke way, you brought to towne wi' yee,
With see saw sacke a downe, like a Sawyer;
Nor in a Comicke Scene, play Hercules furens,
Tearing your throat to split the Audients eares.
And you Sir, you had got a tricke of late,
Of holding out your bum in a set speech;
Your fingers fibulating on your breast,
As if your Buttons, or your Band-strings were
Helpes to your memory. Let me see you in't
No more I charge you. No, nor you sir, in
That over-action of the legges I told you of,
Your singles, and your doubles, Looke you— thus—
Like one o'th' dancing Masters o'the Beare-garden;
And when you have spoke, at end of every speech,
Not minding the reply, you turne you round
As Tumblers doe; when betwixt every feat.
They gather wind, by firking up their breeches.
Ile none of these, absurdities in my house.
But words and action married so together,
That shall strike harmony in the eares and eyes
Of the severest, if judicious Criticks.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Goe, be ready:
But you Sir are incorrigible, and
Take licence to your selfe, to adde unto
Your parts, your owne free fancy; and sometimes
To alter, or diminish what the writer
With care and skill compos'd: and when you are
To speake to your coactors in the Scene,
You hold interloquutions with the Audients.

sp.speaker: Bip.
sp.l: That is a way my Lord has bin allow'd
On elder stages to move mirth and laughter.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes in the dayes of Tarlton and Kempe,
Before the stage was purg'd from barbarisme,
And brought to the perfection it now shines with.
Then fooles and jesters spent their wits, because
The Poets were wise enough to save their owne
For profitabler uses. Let that passe.
Tonight, ile give thee leave to try thy wit,
In answering my Doctor, and his Patient
He brings along with him to our Antipodes.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I heard of him my Lord: Blaze gave me light
Of the mad Patient; and that he never saw
A Play in's life: it will be possible
For him to thinke he is in the Antipodes
Indeed, when he is on the Stage among us.
When't has beene thought by some that have their wits,
That all the Players i' th' Towne were sunke past rising.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Leave that sir to th'event. See all be ready:
Your Musicke properties, and—

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: All my Lord,
Onely we want a person for a Mute.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Blaze when he comes shall serve. Goe in. Ex. Byp.
My Guests J heare are comming.

div.head: Act 2. Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter Blaze, Ioylesse, Diana, Martha Barb.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: My Lord, J am become your honours usher,
To these your guests. The worthy Mr. Ioylesse,
With his faire wife, and daughter in law.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: They're welcome,
And you in the first place sweet Mistris Ioylesse.
You weare my ring J see; you grace me in it.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: His Ring! what Ring? how came she by't?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: J sent it as a pledge of my affection to you:
For J before have seene you, and doe languish,
Untill J shall enjoy your love.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Next Lady— you— J have a toy for you too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Child shall thanke you for it, when I have one.
I take no joy in toyes since I was marryed.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Prettily answer'd! I make you no stranger
Kind Mistris Blaze.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Time was your honour us'd
Me strangely too, as you'll doe these I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Honest Blaze,
Prethee goe in, there is an Actor wanting.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Is there a part for me? how shall I study't?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Then if I doe not act
Nothing as well as the best of 'hem, let me be hist. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I say restore the Ring, and backe with me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: To whom shall I restore it?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: To the Lord that sent it.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Is he a Lord? I alwayes thought and heard
Ith' Country, Lords were gallant Creatures. He
Looks like a thing not worth it: tis not his,
The Doctor gave it me, and I will keepe it.

sp.speaker: Let
sp.l: I use small verball courtesie Mr. Ioylesse
(You see) but what I can in deed ile doe.
You know the purpose of your comming, and
I can but give you welcome. If your sonne
Shall receive ease in't, be the comfort yours,
The credit of't my Doctors. You are sad.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: My Lord I would entreat we may returne;
I feare my wife's not well.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Returne I pray slight not so my courtesie.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Besides sir I am well; and have a minde
(A thankfull one) to taste my Lords free bounty.
I never saw a play, and would be loath
To lose my longing now.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: The aire of London
Hath tainted her obedience already:
And should the Play but touch the vices of it,
She'd learne and practise 'hem. Let me beseech
Your Lord ships reacceptance of the un-
Merited favour that she weares here, and
Your leave for our departure.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: J will not
Be so dishonoured; nor become so ill
A master of my house, to let a Lady
Leave it against her will; and from her longing;
J will be plaine wi'yee therefore: If your haste
Must needs post you away, you may depart,
She shall not not till the morning for mine honour.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Indeed tis a high poynt of honour in
A Lord to keepe a private Gentlemans wife
From him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: J love this plaine Lord better than
All the brave gallant ones, that ere I dream't on.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Tis time we take our seats. So if you'll stay.
Come sit with us, if not, you know your way.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Here are we fallen through the Doctors fingers.
Into the Lords hands. Fate deliver us. Ex. omnes.

div.head: Act. 2. Sene 4.
div.stage: Enter in sea-gownes and Caps, Doctor, and Perigrine brought in a chaire by 2 Sailers: Cloaks and Hats brought in.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Now the last minute of his sleeping fit
Determines. Raise him on his feete. So, so:
Rest him upon mine Arme. Remove that Chaire,
Welcome a shore Sir in th' Antipodes.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: And on firme land.
Sailers you may returne now to your ship. Ex. Sail.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What worlds of lands and Seas have I past over,
Neglecting to set downe my observations,
A thousand thousand things remarkable
Have slipt my memory, as if all had beene
Meere shadowy phantasmes, or Phantasticke dreames.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: We'll write as we returne Sir: and tis true,
You slept most part o' th' journey hitherward,
The aire was so somniferous: And twas well
You scap'd the Calenture by't.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: But how long doe you thinke I slept?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Eight moneths, and some odde dayes,
Which was but as so many houres and minutes
Of ones owne naturall Country sleepe.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Eight Moneths—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Twas nothing for so young a Braine.
How thinke you one of the seven Christian Champions,
David by name, slept seven yeares in a Leek-bed.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I thinke I have read it in their famous History.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: But what chiefe thing of note now in our Travells
Can you call presently to mind? Speake like a Traveller.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I doe remember, as we past the Verge
O'th' upper world, comming downe, down-hill,
The setting Sunne then bidding them good night,
Came gliding easily downe by us; and strucke
New day before us, lighting us our way;
But with such heate, that till he was got farre
Before us, we even melted.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Well wrought potion. Very well observ'd sir.
But now we are come into a temperate clime
Of equall composition of elements
With that of London; and as well agreeable
Unto our nature, as you have found that aire.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Cry you mercy.
This Sir is Anti London. That's the' Antipodes
To the grand City of our Nation,
Iust the same people, language, and Religion,
But contrary in Manners, as I ha' told you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I doe remember that relation,
As if you had but given it me this morning.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Now cast your Sea weeds off, and do'n fresh garments.
Hearke sir their Musicke.

div.head: Act 2. Scene 5.
div.stage: Shift. Hoboyes. Enter Letoy, Ioylesse, Diana, Martha, Barara, in Masques, they sit at the other end of the stage.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Here we may sit, and he not see us.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Now see one of the Natives of this Country,
Note his attire, his language, and behaviour.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Our farre fetch'd Title over lands and seas,
Offers unto your view th'Antipodes.
But what Antipodes now shall you see?
Even those that foot to foot 'gainst London be,
Because no Traveller that knowes that state,
Shall say we personate or imitate
Them in our actions: For nothing can
Almost be spoke, but some or other man,
Takes it unto himselfe; and sayes the stuffe,
If it be vicious, or absurd enough.
Was woven upon his backe. Farre, farre be all
That bring such prejudice mixt with their gall.
This play shall no Satyrick Timist be
To taxe or touch at either him or thee,
That art notorious. Tis so farre below
Things in our orbe, that doe among us flow,
That no degree, from Keyser to the Clowne,
Shall say this vice or folly was mine owne.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: This had bin well now, if you had not dreamt
Too long upon your sillables. Ex. Prol.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: The Prologue call you this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Tis my Lords Reader, and as good a lad
Out of his function, as I would desire
To mixe withall in civill conversation.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes Lady, this was Prologue to the Play,
As this is to our sweet ensuing pleasures. Kisse.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Kissing indeed is Prologue to a Play,
Compos'd by th'Divell, and acted by the Children
Of his blacke Revells, may hell take yee for't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed I am weary, and would faine goe home.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Indeed but you must stay; and see the play.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The Play: what play? It is no Childrens play,
Nor no Child-getting play, pray is it?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You'll see anon. O now the Actors enter. Flourish.

div.head: Act 2. Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter two Sergeants, with swords drawne, running before a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why doe you not your office courteous friends?
Let me entreat you stay, and take me with you;
Lay but your hands on mee: I shall not rest
untill I be arrested. A sore shoulder-ache
Paines and torments me, till your vertuous hands
Doe clap or stroake it.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: And I beseech you pardon our intent,
Which was indeed to have arrested you:
But sooner shall the Charter of the City
Be forfeited, then varlets (like our selves)
Shall wrong a Gentlemans peace. So fare you well sir. Ex.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Two Catchpoles
Runne from a Gentleman (it seemes) that would
Have bin arrested.

div.head: Act 2. Scene 7.
div.stage: Enter old Lady and By play, like a Servingman.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yonder's your Master,
Goe take him you in hand, while I fetch breath,

sp.speaker: Bip.
sp.l: O are you here? my Lady, and my selfe
Have sought you sweetly.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: You, and your Lady, you
Should ha' said Puppy.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: For we heard you were
To be arrested. Pray sir, who has bail'd you?
I wonder who of all your bold acquaintance
That knowes my Lady durst baile off her husband.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Have you not made
An end by composition, and disburs'd
Some of my Ladies money for a peace
That shall beget an open warre upon you?
Confesse it if you have: for 'twill come out.
She'll ha' you up you know. I speak it for your good.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I know't, and ile entreate my Lady wife
To mend thy wages tother forty shillings
A yeare, for thy true care of me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Tis well Sir,
But now (if thou hast impudence so much,
As face to face, to speak unto a Lady
That is thy wife, and supreame head) tell me
At whose sute was it? or upon what action?
Debts I presume you have none: For who dares trust
A Ladyes husband, who is but a Squire,
And under covert barne? it is some trespasse—
Answer me not till I finde out the truth.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The truth is—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Peace,
How darst thou speake the truth
Before thy wife? ile finde it out my selfe.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: In truth she handles him handsomely.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Yes, and such wives are worthy to be lik'd,
For giving good example.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Good! hold up
That humour by all meanes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I thinke I ha' found it.
There was a certaine Mercer sent you silkes,
And cloth of gold to get his wife with child;
You slighted her, and answered not his hopes;
And now he layes to arrest you; is't not so?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Indeed my Lady wife tis so.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: For shame
Be not ingratefull to that honest man,
To take his wares, and scorne to lye with his wife.
Do't I command you; what did I marry you for?
The portion that you brought me was not so
Aboundant, though it were five thousand pounds
(Considering too the Joincture that I made you)
That you should disobey me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: It seemes the husbands
In the Antipodes bring portions, and
The wives make Joinctures.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And wives, when they are old, and past child-bearing,
Allow their youthfull husbands other women.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Right. And old men give their young wives like licence.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That I like well. Why should not our old men,
Love their young wives as well?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Peace master Ioylesse, you are too lowd. Good still,

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Doe as my Lady bids, you got her woman
With child at halfe these words.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O, but anothers
Wife is another thing. Farre be it from
A Gentlemans thought to doe so, having a wife
And hand-mayd of his owne that he likes better.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: There said you well; but take heed I advise you
How you love your owne wench, or your owne wife
Better then other mens.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Goe to that woman, if she prove with childe,
I'll take it as mine owne.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: her husband would
Doe so. But from my house I may not stray.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If it be me your wife commends you to,
You shall not need to stray from your owne house.
I'll goe home with you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Precious! what doe you meane?
Pray keepe your seat: you'll put the players out.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Here's goodly stuffe! Shee's in the Antipodes too.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: All Antipodeans.
Attend good Sir.

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: You know your charge, obey it.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: What is his charge? or whom must he obey?
Good madam with your wilde authority;
You are his wife, tis true, and therein may
According to our law, rule, and controwle him.
But you must know withall, I am your servant,
And bound by the same law to governe you,
And be a stay to you in declining age,
To curbe and qualifie your head-strong will,
Which otherwise would ruine you. Moreover,
Though y'are his wife, I am a breeding mother,
Of a deare childe of his; and therein claime
More honor from him then you ought to challenge.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: You have something there to looke to, one would thinke,
If you had any care. How well you saw
Your father at Schoole to day, and knowing how apt
He is to play the Trewant.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But is he not
Yet gone to schoole?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Stand by, and you shall see.

div.head: Act. 2. Scene. 9.
div.stage: Enter three old men with sachells, &c.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.p: Domine, domine duster. Three knaves in a cluster, &c.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O this is gallant pastime Nay come on,
Is this your schoole? was that your lesson, ha?

sp.speaker: 1 Old.
sp.p: Pray now good son, indeed, indeed.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Indeed
You shall to schoole, away with him; and take
Their wagships with him; the whole cluster of 'hem.

sp.speaker: 2 Old.
sp.p: You shant send us now, so you shant.

sp.speaker: 3 Old.
sp.p: We be none of your father, so we beant.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Away with 'hem I say; and tell their Schoole-mistris,
What trewants they are, and bid her pay 'hem soundly.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Alasse, will no body beg pardon for
The poore old boyes?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sir, gentle Sir, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: To strangers Sir I can be gentle.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Good,
Now marke that fellow, he speakes Extempore.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Extempore call you him? he's a dogged fellow
To the three poore old things there, fie upon him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Do men of such faire years here go to schoole?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Have you no young men schollers, sir I pray;
When we have beard lesse doctors?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: He has wip'd my lips, you question very wisely Sir.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: So sir have wee; and many reverend teachers,
Grave counsellors at law; perfect statesmen.
That never knew use of Rasor, which may live
For want of wit to loose their offices.
These were great schollers in their youth. But when
Age growes upon men here, their learning wasts,
And so decayes; that if they live untill
Threescore, their sons send them to schoole againe.
They'd dye as speechlesse else as new born children.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Tis a wise nation; and the piety
Of the young men most rare and commendable,
Yet give me as a stranger leave to beg
Their liberty this day; and what they loose by't,
My father when he goes to schoole, shall answer.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I am abus'd on that side too.

sp.speaker: Bypt.
sp.l: Tis granted.
Hold up your heads and thanke the gentleman
Like schollers, with your heeles now.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Gratias, Gratias, Gratias.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Well done sonne Peregrine, he's in's wits I hope.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: If you lose yours the while, where's my advantage?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And trust me, twas well done too of Extempore
To let the poore old children loose. And now
I looke well on him he's a proper man.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: She'll fall in love with the Actor, and undoe me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Do's not his Lady love him, sweet my Lord?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Love; yes, and lye with him, as her husband do's
With's mayd. It is their law in the Antipodes.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: But we have no such lawes with us.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Doe you approve of such a law?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: No; not so much
In this case, where the man and wife doe lye
With their inferiour servants; But in the other,
Where the old Citizen would arrest the gallant
That tooke his wares and would not lye with's wife,
There it seemes reasonable, very reasonable.

sp.speaker: Dia
sp.l: Mak't your owne case, you are an old man,
I love a gentleman, you give him rich presents,
To get me a child (because you cannot) must not
We looke to have our bargaine?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Give me leave
Now to be gone my Lord, though I leave her
Behinde me; shee is mad, and not my wife,
And I may leave her.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Come; you are mov'd I see,
I'll settle all; But first, prevaile with you
To taste my wine and sweet meats. The Comedians
Shall pause the while. This you must not deny me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I must not live here alwaies, that's my comfort. Exit.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir, for the poore mens release,
It was the first request that I have made
Since I came in these confines.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Tis our custome
To deny strangers nothing: yea, to offer
Of any thing we have, that may be usefull,
In curtesie to strangers. Will you therefore
Be pleas'd to enter Sir this habitation,
And take such vyands, beverage, and repose
As may refresh you after tedious travailes?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Thou tak'st him right: for I am sure he's hungry.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: All I have seene since my arrivall, are
Wonders. But your humanity excells.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: Vertue in the Antipodes onely dwells.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: YEt, Mr. Ioylesse, are you pleas'd? you see
Here's nothing but faire play, and all above boord.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: But it is late, and these long intermissions
By banqueting and Courtship twixt the Acts
Will keep backe the Catastrophe of your play,
Vntill the morning light.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: And then in midst of Scenes
You interrupt your Actors; and tye them
To lengthen time in silence, while you hold
Discourse, by th'by.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Poxe o'thy jealousie.
Because I give thy wife a looke, or word
Sometimes! What if I kisse (thus) Ile not eate her.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Soe, so, his banquet workes with him.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And for my Actors, they shall speake, or not speake
As much, or more, or lesse, and when I please,
It is my way of pleasure, and ile use it.
So sit: They enter. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Your case is cleare, I understand it fully,
And need no more instructions, this shall serve,
To firke your Adversary from Court to Court,
If he stand out upon rebellious Legges,
But till Octabis Michaelis next.
Ile bring him on submissive knees.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: A Lawyer, and his Clyent there, a Poet.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Goes Law so torne, and Poetry so brave?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Will you but give the Actors leave to speake,
They may have done the sooner?

sp.speaker: Law
sp.l: Let me see,
This is your bill of Parcells.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Yes, of all
My severall wares, according to the rates
Delivered unto my debitor,

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes, Poetry is good ware
In the Antipodes, though there be some ill payers,
As well as here; but Law there rights the Poets.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Delivered too, and for the use of the right worshipfull
Mr. Alderman Humblebee, as followeth— Imprimis— Reads.
Umh, I cannot read your hand; your Character
Is bad, and your Orthography much worse.
Read it your selfe pray.

sp.speaker: Dia
sp.l: Doe Aldermen
Love Poetry in Antipodea London.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Better than ours doe Custards; but the worst
Pay-masters living there; worse than our gallants,
Partly for want of money, partly wit.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Can Aldermen want wit and money too?
That's wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Imprimis sir here is
For three religious Madrigalls to be sung
By th' holy Vestalls in Bridewell, for the
Conversion of our City wives and daughters,
Ten groats a peece, it was his owne agreement.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Item, twelve Hymnes,
For the twelve Sessions, during his Shrievalty,
Sung by the Quire of New-gate, in the praise
Of City Clemency (for in that yeare
No guiltlesse person suffer'd by their judgement)
Ten groats a peece also.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Why speaks your Poet so demurely?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Oh—
Tis a precise tone he has got among
The sober sister-hood.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh I remember,
The Doctor said Poets were all Puritans
In the Antipodes: But where's the Doctor?
And where's your sonne my Ioylesse?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Item,
A Disticke graven in his thumb-ring,
Of all the wise speeches and sayings of all
His Alder Predecessors, and his brethren
In two Kings reignes.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Two peeces he promised to me for it.
Item, inscriptions in his Hall and Parlour,
His Gallery, and garden, round the walls,
Of his owne publicke acts, betweene the time
He was a Common Councell man and shriefe,
One thousand lines put into wholsome verse.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Here's a summe towards indeed! a thousand verses?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: They come too, at the known rate of the City.
(That is to say at forty pence the score)
Eight pounds sixe shillings, eight pence.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Item, an Elegy for Mistris Alderwoman
Upon the death of one of her Coach-mares,
She priz'd above her daughter, being crooked—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tis true, for I should weep for that poore daughter,
Tis like she'll have no children, pray now looke,
Am not I crooked too?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Item, a love Epistle for the Aldermanikin his sonne,
And a Booke of the godly life and death
Of Mistris Katherine Stubs, which I have turn'd
Into sweet meetre, for the vertuous youth,
To woe an ancient Lady widow with.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Heres a large summe in all, for which ile try,
His strength in law, till he peccavi cry,
When I shall sing, for all his present bignesse,
Iamque opus exegi quod nec Iovis Ira, nec ignis.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: The Lawyer speaks the Poets part.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: He thinkes
The more; the Poets in th' Antipodes,
Are slow of tongue, but nimble with the pen.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: The counsaile and the comfort you have given
Me, requires a double fee. Offers mony.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Will you abuse me therefore?
I take no fees double nor single I.
Retaine your money, you retaine not me else.
Away, away, you'll hinder other Clyents.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to send then to your wife.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Not so much as a Poesie for her thimble,
For feare I spoyle your cause,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: What a poore honest Lawyer's this?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: They are all so
In th' Antipodes.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Y'are welcome Captaine.
In your two causes I have done my best.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And whats the issue pray sir?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Truely sir,
Our best course is not to proceed to triall.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Your reason? I shall then recover nothing.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Yes, more by composition, than the Court
Can lawfully adjudge you, as I have labour'd.
And sir, my course is, where I can compound
A difference, Ile not tosse nor bandy it
Into the hazzard of a judgement.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Still
An honest Lawyer, and tho poore, no marvaile.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: First you understand
Your severall actions, and your adversaries,
The first a Battery against a Coach-man,
That beate you sorely.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: What hard hearted fellow
Could beat so spruce a gentleman, and a captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: By this faire hilt, he did sir, and so bruis'd
My armes, so crush'd my ribs, and stich'd my sides,
That I have had no heart to draw my sword since;
And shall I put it up, and not his purse
Be made to pay for't?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: It is up already, sir,
If you can be advis'd, observe I pray,
Your other actions 'gainst your feathermaker,
And that of trespasse for th'incessant trouble
He puts you to by importunate requests,
To pay him no money, but take longer day.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Against all humane reason, for although
I have bought feathers of him these foure yeares,
And never paid him a penny; yet he duns me
So desperately to keepe my money still,
As if I ought him nothing; he haunts and breaks my sleepes.
I sweare sir, by the motion of this I weare now, Shakes it.
I have had twenty better feathers of him, and as ill paid for,
Yet still he duns me to forbeare my payment,
And to take longer day.
I ha'not said my prayers in
Mine owne lodging sir this twelvemonths day,
For sight or thought of him; and how can you
Compound this action, or the other of
That Russian Coachman that durst lift a hand
'Gainst a Commander.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Very easily thus,
The Coachman's poore, and scarce his twelvemoneths wages
Tho't be five markes a yeare will satisfie.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Pray name no summe in markes, I have had too many
Of's markes already.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: So you owe the other
A debt of twenty pound, the Coachman now
Shall for your satisfaction, beat you out
Of debt.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: No sir he shall beate
For you your feather man till he take his money.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: So Ile be satisfied, and helpe him to
More customers of my ranke.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Leave it to me then,
It shall be by posterity repeaten
That souldiers ought not to be dund or beaten,
Away and keepe your money.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: An honest lawyer, still how he considers
The weake estate of a young Gentleman
At armes— But who comes here? a woman.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes; that has taken up the newest fashion
Of the towne-militasters.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Is it Buffe,
Or Calfe skin troe? she lookes as she cold beate
Out a whole Taverne garison before her
Of mill tasters call you 'em? if her husband
Be an old jealous man now, and can please her Lawyer reads on papers.
No better then most ancient husbands can,
I warrant she makes her selfe good upon him.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Tis very good, the play begins to please me.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: I wayt to speake w'yee sir, but must I stand
Your constring and piercing of your scriblings.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Thus farre I have proceeded in your cause
Ith' Marshalls court.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: But shall I have the combate?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Pray observe
The passages of my proceedings; and
The pro's and contras in the windings, workings
And carriage of the cause.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Fah on your passages,
Your windy workings, and your fislings at
The barre. Come me toth' poynt, is it decreed,
A combate?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Well, it is; and heer's your order.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Now thou hast spoken like a lawyer,
And heer's thy fee.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Take it, or I will beat thy carcasse thinner
Then thou hast worne thy gowne here.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Must I then take you in hand?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Alas poore man, he will take money yet,
Rather then blowes, and so farre he agrees
With our rich lawyers, that sometimes give blowes
And shrewd ones for their money.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Now victory
Affoord me fate, or bravely let me dye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: You shall see that anon—

div.head: Act. 3. Scene. 5.
div.stage: Enter a Beggar, and a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: What's here, what's here?
A Courtier, or some gallant practising
The beggars trade, who teaches him I thinke.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Sir excuse me, I have
From time to time supplyed you without hope,
Or purpose to receive least retribution
From you, no not so much as thankes or bare
Acknowledgement of the free benefits,
I have confer'd upon you.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Yet doe you now when that my present store
Responds not my occasions, seeke to oppresse me
With vaine petitionary breath, for what I may not
Give without feare of dangerous detriment?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: In what a phrase the ragged Orator
Displayes himselfe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: The Beggars are the
Most absolute Courtiers in th' Antipodes.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: If not a peece, yet spare me halfe a peece
For goodnesse sake good sir, did you but know
My instant want, and to what vertuous use,
I would distribute it, I know you would not
Hold backe your charity.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And how feelingly
He begges; then as the beggers are the best
Courtiers, it seemes the Courtiers are best beggers
In the Antipodes; how contrary in all
Are they to us?

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Pray to what vertuous uses
Would you put money to now, if you had it?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: I would bestow a crowne in Ballads,
Love-pamphlets, and such poeticall Rarities,
To send downe to my Lady Grandmother.
She's very old you know, and given much
To contemplation; I know she'l send me for 'em,
In Puddings, Bacon, Sowse and Pot-Butter
Enough to keepe my chamber all this winter.
So shall I save my fathers whole allowance
To lay upon my backe, and not be forc'd
To shift out from my study for my victualls.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: I would bestow another crowne in
Hobby-horses, and Rattles for my Grand-father,
Whose legges and hearing faile him very much,
Then to preserve his sight a Jack-a-lent,
In a greene sarsnet suite, he'l make my father
To send me one of Scarlet, or hee'l cry
His eyes out for't.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: I have but just a fee left for my Lawyer;
If he exact not that, Ile give it thee.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He'l take no fee (that's sure enough young man)
Of beggars, I know that.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Ile speake to him my selfe else to remit it.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You will not sure, will you turne Actor too?
Pray doe, be put in for a share amongst em?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: How must I be put in?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: The Players will quickly
Shew you, if you performe your part; perhaps
They may want one to act the whore amongest 'em.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Fye Master Ioylesse, y'are too fowle.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: My Lord,
She is too faire it seemes in your opinion,
For me, therefore if you can finde it lawfull,
Keepe her; I will be gone.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Now I protest
Sit and sit civilly, till the play be done,
Ile lock thee up else, as I am true Letoy.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Nay I ha' done— Whistles Fortune my foe.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Give me my fee, I cannot heare you else.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Sir I am poore, and all I get, is at
The hands of charitable givers; pray sir.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: You understand me sir, your cause is to be
Pleaded to day, or you are quite orethrowne in't.
The Judge by this tyme is about to sit.
Keepe fast your money, and forgoe your wit. Exit.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Then I must follow, and entreate him to it,
Poore men in law must not disdaine to doe it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Doe it then, Ile follow you and heare the cause. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: True Antipodians still, for as with us,
The Gallants follow Lawyers, and the beggers them;
The Lawyer here is follow'd by the begger,
While the gentleman followes him.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: The morall is, the Lawyers here prove beggers,
And beggers only thrive by going to law.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: How takes the Lawyers then the beggers money?
And none else by their wills?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: They send it all
Up to our lawyers, to stop their mouths,
That curse poore Clyents that are put upon 'em.
In forma Pauperis.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: In truth most charitable,
But sure that money's lost by'th way sometimes.
Yet sweet my Lord, whom doe these beggers beg of,
That they can get aforehand so for law?
Who are their benefactors?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Then they have Usurers in th' Antipodes too?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes Usury goes round the world, and will doe,
Till the generall conversion of the Jewes.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: But ours are not so charitable I feare.
Who be their Usurers?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Souldiers, and Courtiers chiefly;
And some that passe for grave and pious Church-men.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: How finely contrary th'are still to ours.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Why doe you not enter, what are you asleepe?—

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: My Lord the madde young Gentleman.—

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: He has got into our Tyring-house amongst us,
And tane a strict survey of all our properties,
Our statues and our images of Gods; our Planets and our constellations
Our Giants, Monsters, Furies, Beasts, and Bug-Beares,
Our Helmets Shields, and Vizors, Haires, and Beards,
Our Pastbord March-paines, and our Wooden Pies.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Sirrah be briefe, be not you now as long in
Telling what he saw, as he surveying.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Whether he thought t'was some inchanted Castle,
Or Temple, hung and pild with Monuments
Of uncouth, and of various aspects,
I dive not to his thoughts, wonder he did
A while it seem'd, but yet undanted stood:
When on the suddaine, with thrice knightly force,
And thrice, thrice, puissant arme he snatcheth downe
The sword and shield that I playd Bevis with,
Rusheth amongst the foresaid properties,
Kils Monster, after Monster; takes the Puppets
Prisoners, knocks downe the Cyclops, tumbles all
Our jigambobs and trinckets to the wall.
Spying at last the Crowne and royall Robes
Ith upper wardrobe, next to which by chance,
The divells vizors hung, and their flame painted
Skin coates; those he remov'd with greater fury,
And (having cut the infernall ugly faces,
All into mamocks) with a reverend hand,
He takes the imperiall diadem and crownes
Himselfe King of the Antipodes, and beleeves
He has justly gaind the Kingdome by his conquest.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Doctor Hughball
Hath sooth'd him in't, so that nothing can
Be said against it, he begins to governe
With purpose to reduce the manners
Of this country to his owne, h'has constituted
The Doctor his chiefe officer; whose Secretary
I am to be, you'l see a Court well orderd.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I see th'event already, by the ayme Letoy wispers With Barbara.
The Doctor takes, proceed you with your play,
And let him see it in what state he pleases.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Trust me, this same Extempore,
(I know not's tother name) pleases me better
For absolute action then all the rest.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: You were best beg him of his Lord.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Say you so?
He's busie, or Ide move him,

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Prithee doe so,
Good Mistres Blaze; goe with her gentle Lady. to Marth.
Doe as she bids you, you shall get a child by't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ile doe as any body bids me for a childe.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Diana yet be wise, beare not the name
Of sober chastity to play the beast in.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Thinke not your selfe, nor make your selfe a beast,
Before you are one, and when you appeare so,
Then thanke your selfe; your jealousie durst not trust me,
Behinde you in the country, and since Ime here,
Ile see and know, and follow th'fashion; if
It be to cuckold you, I cannot helpe it.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: I now could wish my sonne had beene as farre
In the Antipodes as he thinkes himselfe,
Ere I had runne this hazzard.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And Ile perform't I warrant you my Lord. Ex. Ba. Mar.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why should you wish so? had you rather loose
Your son then please your wife? you shew your love both waies.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing.—

div.head: Act. 3. Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter Byplay the Governour, Mace-bearer, Sword-bearer, Officer, the Mace and Sword laid on the Table, the Governour sits.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: No tis the City Governor,
And the chiefe Judge within their Corporation.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Here's a City Enter Peregine and Doctor.
Like to be well govern'd then.—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Yonder's a king, doe you know him?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Tis your sonne,
My Ioylesse, now y'are pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Would you were pleas'd,
To cease your huswifry in spinning out
The Play at length thus.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Heere sir, you shall see
A poynt of Justice handled.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: Call the defendant, and the Plaintiffe in.

sp.speaker: Byp:
sp.l: How now!
How long ha you beene free oth Poyntmakers,
Good master hilt and scaberd carrier;
(Which is in my hands now) do you give order
For counsell and for witnesses in a cause
Fit for my hearing, or for me to judge, haw?
I must be rul'd and circumscrib'd by Lawyers must I,
And witnesses haw? no you shall know
I can give judgement, be it right or wrong,
Without their needlesse proving and defending:
So bid the Lawyers goe and shake their eares,
If they have any, and the witnesses,
Preserve their breath to prophesie of dry summers.
Bring me the plaintiffe, and defendant only:
But the defendant first, I will not heare
Any complaint before I understand
What the defendant can say for himselfe.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I have not known such down right equity,
If he proceeds as he begins, ile grace him.—

sp.speaker: By.
sp.p: Now sir, are you the plaintiffe or defendant, haw?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Both as the case requires my Lord.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: I cannot
Heare two at once, speake first as y'are defendant.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: I will heare no
Complaint, I say speake your defence.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: For silkes and
Stuffes receiv'd by me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes my good Lord, he doth not now complain.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: For money nor for wares
Againe: but he complaines.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.p: Complaines againe? do you double with me, haw?

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Of his wife, does he, haw? That I must confesse
Is many a good mans case; you may proceed.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: In money I tender him double satisfaction,
With his own wares again unblemished, undishonor'd.

sp.speaker: Dia
sp.l: What an odde
Jeering Judge is this?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But unto me,
They were deliverd upon this condition,
That I should satisfie his wife.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Heel have
Your body for her then, unlesse I empt
My brest of mercy to appease her for you,
Call in the plaintiffe; sir, stand you aside. Exit Officer.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh tis the flinching Gentleman that broake
With the kind citizens wife. J hope the Judge
Will make him an example.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Come you forwards,
Yet nerer man, J know my face is terrible,
And that a Citizen had rather lose
His debt, then that a Judge should truely know
His dealings with a gentleman, yet speake,
Repeat without thy shop booke now; and without
Feare, it may rise in judgement here against thee.
What is thy full demand? what satisfaction
Requirest thou of this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: And please you sir—

sp.speaker: By.
