sp.l: Twas well said Sword-bearer,
Thou knowst thy place, which is to shew correction.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: My Lord an't please you, if it like your honour.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: La! an intelligent Citizen, and may grow
In time himselfe to sit in place of worship.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: I aske no satisfaction of the gentleman,
But to content my wife; what her demand is,
Tis best knowne to her selfe; please her, please me,
An't please you sir— My Lord an't like your honour.
But before he has given her satisfaction,
I may not fall my suit, nor draw my action.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: No alacke a day I may not,
Nor find content, nor peace at home, and't please you
(My Lord, an't like your honour I would say)
An't please you, what's a tradesman, that
Has a faire wife, without his wife, an't please you?
And she without content is no wife, considering
We trades-men live by gentlemen, an't please you,
And our wives drive a halfe trade with us, if the gentlemen
Breake with our wives, our wives are no wives to us,
And we but broken Trades-men, an't please you.
And't like your honour, my good Lord, and't please you.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Yet gentlemen,
A lacke a day, and please you, and like your honour,
Will not consider our necessities,
And our desire in general through the City,
To have our sonnes all gentlemen like them.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Nor though a gentleman consume
His whole estate among ye, yet his sonne
May live t'inherit it?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Right, right, and't please you:
Your honour my good Lord and't please you.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Well,
This has so little to be said against it,
That you say nothing. Gentlemen it seems
Y'are obstinate, and will stand out—

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My Lord,
Rather then not to stand out with all mens wives,
Except mine owne, ile yield me into prison.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: If our young gentlemen,
Were like those of th'Antipodes, what decay
Of trade would here bee, and how full the prisons?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I offer him any other satisfaction;
His wares againe, or money twice the value.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: I, I, alacke a day,
Nor doe I sue to have him up in prison,
Alacke a day, what good (good gentleman)
Can I get by his body?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Peace, I should
Now give my sentence, and for your contempt,
(which is a great one, such as if let passe
Unpunished, may spread forth a dangerous
Example, to the breach of City custome,
By gentlemens neglect of Tradesmens wives)
I should say for this contempt commit you
Prisoner from sight of any other woman,
Untill you give this mans wife satisfaction,
And she release you; justice so would have it:
But as I am a Citizen by nature,
(For education made it so) ile use
Urbanity in your behalfe towards you;
And as I am a gentleman by calling,
(For so my place must have it) ile performe
For you the office of a gentleman
Towards his wife, I therefore order thus;
That you bring me the wares here into Court,
(I have a chest shall hold 'hem, as mine owne)
And you send me your wife, ile satisfie her
My selfe. Ile do't, and set all streight and right:
Justice is blinde, but Judges have their sight.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And feeling too in the Antipodes.
Han't they my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: What's that to you my Lady?
Within .Dismisse the Court.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Dismisse the Court, cannot you heare the prompter?
Ha' you lost your eares, Judge?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: No: dismisse the Court,
Embrace you friends, and to shun further strife,
See you send me your stuffe, and you your wife.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Protest Extempore plaid the Judge; and I
Knew him not all this while.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: What over-sight
Was there?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He is a properer man methinks
Now, than he was before: sure I shall love him.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Sure, sure, you shall not, shall you?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And I warrant,
By his Judgement speech ee'n now, he loves a woman well:
For he said, if you noted him, that he
Would satisfie the Citizens wife himselfe.
Methinks a gentlewoman might please him better.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: How dare you talke so? Byplay kneeles, and kisses Peregrines hand.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: What's he a doing now troe?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Kneele downe
Againe. Give me a sword some body.

sp.speaker: Let
sp.p: The King's about to Knight him.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Let me pray
Your Majesty be pleased, yet to with-hold
That undeserved honour, till you first
Vouchsafe to grace the City with your presence,
Accept one of our Hall-feasts, and a freedome,
And freely use our purse for what great summes
Your Majesty will please.

sp.speaker: Dia
sp.l: What subjects there are
In the Antipodes.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: None in the world so loving.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Give me a sword, I say, must I call thrice?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: No, no, take mine my Liege.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: A loyall Lord, one of your subjects too.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He may be loyall; he's a wondrous plaine one,

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Pritheee Diana, yet lets slip away
Now while he's busie.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: But where's your daughter in Law?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Gone home I warrant you with Mistris Blaze.
Let them be our example.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Y'are an impudent whore,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I know not what I may be
Made by your jealousie.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ile none o' this,
Give me that Princely weapon.

sp.speaker: Sword.
sp.l: It is a property you know my Lord,
No blade, but a rich Scabbard with a Lath in't.

sp.speaker: Let
sp.p: So is the sword of Justice for ought he knows.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Yet on me let it fall,
Since tis your highnesse will, Scabbard and all.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Rise up our trusty well beloved Knight.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Let me finde favour in your gracious sight
To taste a banquet now, which is prepar'd,
And shall be by your followers quickly shar'd.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Come Sirs quickly. Ent. 5. or 6. Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Tis well, lead on the way.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And must not we
Goe to the Banquet too?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: He must not see
You yet; I have provided otherwise
For both you in my Chamber, and from thence
Wee'll at a window see the rest oth' Play,
Or if you needs sir will stay here, you may.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: Was ever man betray'd thus into torment? Ex.

div.head: Act 4. Scene. 1.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: NOw sir be pleas'd to cloud your Princely raiment
With this disguise. Great Kings have done the like,
To make discovery of passages Puts on a Cloake and Hat.
Among the people: thus you shall perceive
What to approve, and what correct among 'hem.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And so ile cherish, or severely punish.

div.stage: Enter an old woman reading: to her, a young Maid.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Royall pastime, in a great match betweene the Tanners and the Butchers, sixe dogges of a side, to play single at the game Bear, for fifty pound, and a tenne pound supper, for their dogs and themselves. Also you shall see two ten dogge-courses at the Great Beare.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Fie Granny fie, can no perswasions,
Threatnings, nor blowes prevaile, but you'll persist
In these prophane and Diabolicall courses,
To follow Bear baitings, when you can scarce
Spell out their Bills with spectacles?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: What though
My sight be gone beyond the reach of Spectacles,
In any print but this, and though I cannot,
(No, no, I cannot read your meditations) strikes downe her book.
Yet I can see the Royall game plaid over and over,
And tell which dogge does best, without my Spectacles.
And though I could not, yet I love the noyse;
The noyse revives me, and the Bear-garden scent
Refresheth much my smelling.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Let me entreat you
Forbeare such beastly pastimes, th'are Sathanicall.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Take heed Child what you say, tis the Kings game.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: A Beare's a Princely beast, and one side Venison
(Writ a good Author once) you yet want yeares,
And are with Bawbles pleas'd, ile see the Beares. Exit.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: And I must beare with it. she's full of wine,
And for the present wilfull; but in due
Season ile humble her: but we are all
Too subject to infirmity.

div.head: Act 4. Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter a yong Gentleman, and an old Serving-man.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Yes sir, old servants are
But Boyes to Masters, be they nere so young.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Take mine, and keepe you warme then,
Ile weare yours.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Out you Varlet,
Dost thou obscure it, as thou meantst to pawne it?
Is this a Cloake unworthy of the light?
Publish it sirrah:— oh presumptuous slave,
Display it on one arme— oh ignorance!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Pray load your Asse your selfe, as you would have it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Nay prethee be not angry: Thus, and now
Be sure you bear't at no such distance; but
As't may be knowne appendix to this booke.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This custome I have seene with us.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Yes, but
It was deriv'd from the Antipodes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: It is a dainty creature, and my blood
Rebells against the spirit: I must speake to him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir here's a Gentlewoman makes towards you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Me? she's deceiv'd, I am not for her mowing.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Faire sir, may you vouchsafe my company?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No truly, I am none of those you look for.
The way is broad enough, unhand me pray you.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Pray sir be kinder to a lasse that loves you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Some such there are, but I am none of those.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Come, this is but a Coppy of your Countenance.
I ha knowne you better than you thinke I doe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: What ha you knowne me for?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I knew you once
For halfe a peece I take it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd
The whole breadth of your nose, I scorne it.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Come be not coy, but send away your servant,
And let me gi' you a pint of wine.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Pray keepe
Your courtesie, I can bestow the wine
Vpon my selfe, if I were so dispos'd,
To drinke in Tavernes; fah.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Let me bestow't
Vpon you at your lodging then; and there
Be civilly merry.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Which if you doe,
My wife shall thanke you for it; but your better
Course is to seeke one fitter for your turne,
You'll lose your aime in me; and I befriend you
To tell you so.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Gip gaffer Shotten, fagh,
Take that for your coy Counsell. Kicks.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Peace good Master,
And come away. Some Cowardly Jade I warrant,
That durst not strike a woman.

div.head: Act 4. Scene 3.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: But and we were your match.—

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: What would you doe?
Come, come afore the Constable: now if
You were her match, what would you doe sir?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Doe?
They have done too much already sir: a Virgin weeps.
Shall not passe shortly for these street-walkers,
If some judicious order be not taken.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir, speake to your companions,
I have a wife and daughters, and am bound,
By hourely precepts, to heare women first,
Be't truth, or no truth, therefore virgin speake,
And feare no bug beares, I will doe thee justice.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: Sir, they assayld me, and with violent hands,
When words could not prevaile, they would have drawne mee
Aside unto their lust till I cryed murder.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Protest Sir, as I am a gentleman,
And as my man's a man she beat us both,
Till I cryd murder.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You are a party, and no witnesse sir,
Besides y'are two, and one is easier
To be beleev'd: moreover as you have the oddes
In number, what were justice, if it should not support
The weaker side? Away with them to the Counter.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Here's much to be reform'd, young man thy vertue
Hath wonne my favour, goe, thou art at large.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He puts me out, my part is now
To bribe the Constable.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: No matter goe— Exit. Gent. and Servant.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And you sir, take that sober seeming wanton,
And clap her up, till I heare better of her,
Ile strip you of your office and your eares else.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: They are an ignorant nation,
And have my pitty mingled with correction:
And therefore, damsell (for you are the first
Offender I have noted here, and this
Your first offence (for ought I know)

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Goe and transgresse no more,
And as you finde my mercy sweet, see that
You be not cruell to your grandmother,
When she returnes from beare-baiting.

div.stage: Enter Buffe woman, her head and face bleeding, and many women, as from a Prize.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: A woman Fencer, that has plaid a Prize,
It seemes, with Losse of blood.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It doth amaze me. They passe over.
What can her husband be, when shee's a Fencer?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: He keepes a Schoole, and teacheth needle-worke,
Or some such Arts which we call womanish.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Tis most miraculous and wonderfull.
Man scould within .Rogues, Varlets, Harlots, ha you done
Your worst, or would you drowne me? would you take my life?
Women within .Ducke him againe, ducke him againe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Some man it seemes, that's duckt for scolding.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: So, so,
Enough, enough, he will be quiet now.

sp.speaker: Mansc.
sp.l: How know you that, you divell ridden witch you?
How, quiet; why quiet? has not the law past on me,
Over, and over me, and must I be quiet?

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.p: Will you incurre the law the second time?

sp.speaker: Mansc.
sp.l: The lawes the river, ist? yes tis a river,
Through which great men, and cunning, wade, or swimme;
But meane and ignorant must drowne in't; no
You hagges and hel-hounds, witches, bitches, all,
That were the law, the Judge, and Executioners,
To my vexation, I hope to see
More flames about your eares, then all the water
You cast me in can quench.

sp.speaker: 3 Wom.
sp.p: In with him againe, he calls us names.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.p: No, no: I charge yee no.

sp.speaker: Mansc.
sp.l: Was ever harmelesse creature so abus'd?
To be drench'd under water, to learne dumbnesse
Amongst the fishes, as I were forbidden
To use the naturall members I was borne with,
And of them all, the chiefe that man takes pleasure in;
The tongue; Oh me accursed wretch. weepes.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Is this a man?
I aske not by his beard, but by his teares.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.l: This showre will spend the fury of his tongue,
And so the tempest's over.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.l: I am sorry for't,
I would have had him duck'd once more;
But some body will shortly raise the storme
In him againe I hope for us, to make
More holiday-sport of him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sure these are dreames,
Nothing but dreames.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No, doubtlesse we are awake sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Can men and women be so contrary
In all that we hold proper to each sex?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'me glad he takes a taste of sence in that yet.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Twill aske long time and study to reduce
Their manners to our government.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: these are
Low things and easie to be qualified—
But see sir, here come Courtiers, note their manners.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: This was three shillings yesterday, how now!
All gone but this? six pence, for leather soles
To my new greene silke stockings, and a groate
My ordinary in Pompions bak'd with Onions.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: Three pence I lost at Nyne-pines; but I got
Six tokens towards that at Pigeon holes—
'S nayles wheres the rest; is my poake bottome broake?

sp.speaker: 2 Cour.
sp.p: What Iacke! A pox oretake thee not; how dost? kicke.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: What with a vengeance aylst? dost thinke my breech
Is made of Bell mettall? take that. Box o'th eare.

sp.speaker: 2 Cour.
sp.l: Pox rot your hold, let goe my locke, doe thinke
Y'are currying of your Fathers horse againe?

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: Ile teach you to abuse a man behind, They buffet.
Was troubled too much afore.

sp.speaker: 3 Cour.
sp.l: Hay, there boyes, there.
Good boyes are good boyes still. There Will, there Iack.
Not a blow, now he's downe.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.p: There's as proud fall, as stand in Court or City.

sp.speaker: 3 Cour.
sp.l: That's well said Will, troth I commend you both.
How fell you out? I hope in no great anger.

sp.speaker: 2 Cour.
sp.p: For mine owne part I vow I was in jest.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: But I have told you twice and once, Will, jest not
With me behind I never could endure
(Not of a Boy) to put up things behinde:
And that my Tutor knew; I had bin a Schollar else.
Besides you know my sword was nock'd i'th' fashion,
Just here behinde, for my backe-guard and all;
And yet you would do't.
I had a liefe you would take a knife—

sp.speaker: 3 Cour.
sp.l: Come, come,
Y'are friends. Shake hands ile give you halfe a dozen
At the next Ale-house, to set all right and streight.
And a new song; a dainty one; here tis. a Ballad.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: O thou art happy that canst reade—
I would buy Ballads too, had I thy learning.

sp.speaker: 3 Cour.
sp.p: Come, we burn day-light, and the Ale may sowre. Ex.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Call you these Courtiers? They are rude silken Clowns;
As course within, as water-men or Car-men.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Then look on these: Here are of those conditions En. carman, & waterman.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am much oblig'd
Sir, by the plenteous favours your humanity
And noble vertue have conferr'd upon me,
To answer with my service your deservings.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: You speake what I should say. Be therefore pleas'd
T'unload, and lay the wait of your commands
Vpon my care to serve you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Still your Courtesies,
Like waves of a Spring-tide, ore-flow the Bankes
Of your abundant store; and from your Channell,
Or streame of faire affections, you cast forth
Those sweet refreshings on me (that were else
But sterile earth) which cause a gratitude
To grow upon me, humble, yet ambitious
In my Devoire, to doe you best of service.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I shall no more extend my utmost labour,
With Oare and Saile to gaine the lively-hood
Of wife and children, then to set a shore
You, and your faithfull honourers at the haven
Of your best wishes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sir, I am no lesse
Ambitious, to be made the happy meanes.
With whip and whistle, to draw up or drive
All your detractors to the Gallowes.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: See,
Our noble friend.

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.l: Right happily encountred—
I am the just admirer of your vertues.

sp.p: We are, in all, your servants.

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.l: I was in quest,
Of such elect society, to spend
A dinner-time withall.

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.l: Three are the golden Number in a Taverne;
And at the next of best, with the best meate,
And wine the house affoords (if you so please)
We will be competently merry. I
Have receiv'd, lately, Letters from beyond Seas,
Importing much of the occurrences,
And passages of forraigne States. The knowledge
Of all I shall impart to you.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: And I
Have all the new advertisements from both
Our Universities, of what has past
The most remarkably of late.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And from
The Court I have the newes at full,
Of all that was observable this Progresse.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Yes sir: They know not there, they have
A new King here at home.

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.l: Tis excellent!
We want but now, the newes-collecting Gallant
To fetch his Dinner, and Materialls
For his this weeks dispatches.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I dare thinke
The meat and newes being hot upon the Table,
He'll smell his way to't.

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.p: Please you to know yours, sir?

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.l: It shall be as your servant
Then, to prepare your dinner.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Yet tis my obedience Ex.

sp.speaker: Per:
sp.p: Are these but labouring men, and tother Courtiers?

sp.speaker: Doct:
sp.l: Tis common here sir, for your watermen
To write most learnedly, when your Courtier
Has scarce ability to read.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Before I reigne
A Moneth among them, they shall change their notes,
Or ile ordaine a course to change their Coats.
I shall have much to doe in reformation.

sp.speaker: Doct:
sp.p: Patience and Counsell will goe through it sir.

sp.speaker: Per:
sp.l: What if I crav'd? a Counsell from New England?
The old will spare me none.

sp.speaker: Doct:
sp.l: Is this man mad?
My cure goes fairely on. Doe you marvaile that
Poore men out-shine the Courtiers? Looke you sir,
A sicke-man giving counsell to a Physitian:
And there's a Puritan Trades-man, teaching a
Great Traveller to lye: That Ballad-woman
Gives light to the most learned Antiquary
In all the Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: A naturall foole, there, giving grave instructions Those persons passe ouer the Stage in Couples, according as he describes them.
T'a Lord Embassador. That's a Schismatick,
Teaching a Scrivener to keep his cares:
A parish Clearke, there, gives the Rudiments
Of Military Discipline to a Generall:
And there's a Basket maker confuting Bellarmine.

div.head: Act 4. Se. 9.
div.stage: Ent. Byplay like a Statesman. 3. or 4. Projectors with bundles of papers.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: We are saild, I hope,
Beyond the line of madnesse. Now sir, see
A States-man studious for the Common-wealth,
Solicited by Projectors of the Country.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Your Projects are all good I like them wel.
Especially these two; This for th' increase of wooll:
And this for the destroying of Mice: They'r good,
And grounded on great reason. As for yours,
For putting downe the infinite use of Iacks,
(Whereby the education of young children,
In turning spits, is greatly hindred)
It may be look'd into: And yours against
The multiplicity of pocket-watches,
(Whereby much neighbourly familiarity,
By asking, what de'yee gesse it is a Clocke?
Is lost) when every puny Clerke can carry
The time oth' day in's Breeches; This, and these
Hereafter may be looke into: For present;
This for the increase of Wool; that is to say,
By fleying of live horses, and new covering them
With Sheeps-skins, I doe like exceedingly.
And this for keeping of tame Owles in Cities,
To kill up Rats and Mice, whereby all Cats
May be destroyed, as an especiall meanes
To prevent witch-craft and contagion.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Will you honour now,
Be pleas'd to take into consideration
The poore mens suits for Briefes, to get reliefe
By common charity throughout the Kingdome,
Towards recovery of their lost estates.

sp.speaker: Byp:
sp.p: What are they? let me heare.

sp.speaker: Pro:
sp.l: First, here's a Gamster, that sold house and land,
To the knowne value of five thousand pounds,
And by misfortune of the Dice lost all,
To his extreame undoing; having neither
A wife or child to succour him.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: Alas tis lamentable: he deserves much pitty.

sp.speaker: Pro:
sp.p: Then, here's a Bawd, of sixty odde yeares standing.

sp.speaker: Byp:
sp.p: How old was she when she set up?

sp.speaker: Pro:
sp.l: But foure
And twenty, my good Lord. She was both ware
And Merchant; Flesh and Butcher, (as they say)
For the first twelve yeares of her house-keeping:
She's now upon fourescore, and has made markets
Of twice foure thousand choyse virginities;
And twice their number of indifferent geare.
(No riffe raffe was she ever knowne to cope for)
Her life is certifi'd here by the Justices,
Adjacent to her dwelling—

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Quite trade-fallen, my good Lord, now in her dotage;
And desperately undone by ryot.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: 'Lasse good woman,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: She has consum'd in prodigall feasts and Fidlers,
And lavish lendings to debauch'd Comrades,
That suckt her purse, in Jewells, Plate, and money,
To the full value of sixe thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: She shall have a Collection, and deserves it.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Then here are divers more,
Of Pandars, Cheaters, house-and high-way Robbers,
That have got great estates in youth and strength,
And wasted all as fast in wine and Harlots.
Till age o'retooke 'hem, and disabled them,
For getting more

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: For such the Law provides
Reliefe within those Counties, where they practis'd.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Yes, their Law punisheth
The rob'd, and not the thiefe, for surer warning,
And the more safe prevention. I have seene
Folkes whipt for losing of their goods and money,
And the picke-pockets cherish'd.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: The weale publicke,
As it severely punisheth their neglect,
Undone by fire ruines, shipwracke, and the like,
With whips, with brands, and losse of carelesse eares,
Imprisonment, banishment, and sometimes death;
And carefully maintaineth houses of Correction
For decay'd Schollars, and maim'd Souldiers;
So doth it finde reliefe. and almes-houses,
For such as liv'd by Rapine and by Cosenage.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Still worse and worse! abhominable! horrid!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Yet here is one, my Lord, 'bove all the rest,
Whose services have generally bin knowne,
Though now he be a spectacle of pitty:

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The captaine of the Cut-purses, my Lord;
That was the best at's art that ever was,
Is fallen to great decay, by the dead palsie
In both his hands, and craves a large collection.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You shall not get it him.
Doe you provide whips, brands; and ordaine death,
For men that suffer under fire, or shipwracke,
The losse of all their honest gotten wealth:
And finde reliefe for Cheaters, Bawdes, and Thieves?
Ile hang yee all.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Let not our ignorance suffer in your wrath,
Before we understand your highnesse Lawes,
We went by custome, and the warrant, which
We had in your late Predecessors raigne;
But let us know your pleasure, you shall finde
The State and Common-wealth in all obedient,
To alter Custome, Law, Religion, all,
To be conformable to your commands.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Tis a faire protestation: And my mercy
Meets your submission. See you merit it
In your conformity.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Great Sir we shall.
In signe whereof we lacerate these papers. Letoy, Diana, Ioylesse, appeare above.
And lay our necks beneath your Kingly feet.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Stand up you have our favour.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And mine too?
Never was such an actor as Extempore!

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: You were best to flye out of the window to him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Me thinkes I am even light enough to doe it.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I could finde in my heart to Quoit thee at him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: So he would catch me in his armes I car'd not.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Peace both of you, or you'l spoyle all.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: your Grace
Abounds— abounds— your Grace— I say abounds.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Pox o'your mumbling chops; is your braine dry?
Doe you pump?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He has done much my Lord, and may
Hold out a little.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Would you could hold your peace
So long.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Doe you sneap me too my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: I hope his hotter zeale to's actors
Will drive out my wives love-heat.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I had
No need to come hither to be sneape.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Hoyday! The rest will all be lost, we now give over
The play, and doe all by Extempore,
For your sonnes good, to sooth him into's wits.
If you'l marre all, you may. Come nearer cocks-combe,
Ha you forgotten (puppy) my instructions
Touching his subjects, and his marriage?

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: I have all now my Lord.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: A voyce out of the clouds, that doth applaud
Your highnesse welcome to your subjects loves.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: So, now he's in. Sit still, I must goe downe
And set out things in order. Ex.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: A voyce that doth informe me of the tydings
Spread through your kingdome, of your great arrivall;
And of the generall joy your people bring
To celebrate the welcome of their king. Showts within.
Hearke how the countrey shouts with joyfull votes,
Rending the ayre with musick of their throats. drum & trumpets
Hearke how the souldier, with his martiall noise,
Threatens your foes, to fill your Crowne with joyes.
Hearke how the City, with loud harmony, Haughboyes.
Chaunts a free welcome to your majesty.
Heark how the Court prepares your grace to meet Soft musick.
With solemne musick, state and beauty sweet.

div.head: Act 4 Sce. 10.
div.stage: The soft musicke playing. Ent. by two and two, divers Courtiers, Martha after them, like a Queene between two boyes in robes. Her train borne up by Barbara, all the Lords kneele, and kisse Perigrines hand, Martha approaching, be starts backe, but is drawne on by Byplay and the Doctor. Letoy enters and mingles with the rest, and seemes to instruct them all.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: O here's a stately show! looke master Ioylesse:
Your daughter in law presented like a queene
Unto your sonne, I warrant now he'l love her.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Yes, yes, and mistris Blaze is made
The mother of her maides, if she have any:
Perhaps the Antipodian Court has none.
See, see, with what a Majesty he receives 'hem.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: HEalth, wealth, and joy our wishes bring,
All in a welcome to our king:
May no delight be found,
Wherewith he be not crown'd,
Apollo with the Muses,
Who Arts divine infuses,
With their choyce Ghirlonds decke his head;
Love and the graces make his bed:
And to crowne all, let Hymen to his side,
Plant a delicious, chast, and fruitfull Bride.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Now Sir be happy in a marriage choyce,
That shall secure your title of a king.
See sir, your state presents to you the daughter,
The onely childe and heire apparant of
Our late deposed and deceased Soveraigne,
Who with his dying breath bequeath'd her to you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A Crowne secures not an unlawfull marriage.
I have a wife already.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: No: you had sir,
But she's deceast.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: By sure advertisment; and that her fleeting spirit
Is flowne into, and animates this Princesse.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Be not slacke
T'embrace and kisse her Sir. He kisses her and retires.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He kisses sweetly;
And that is more then ere my husband did.
But more belongs then kissing to child-getting;
And he's so like my husband, if you note him,
That I shall but lose time and wishes by him,
No, no, Ile none of him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ile warrant you he shall fulfill your wishes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O but try him you first: and then tell me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: There's a new way indeed to chose a husband!
Yet twere a good one to barre foole getting.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why doe you stand aloofe Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Mandivell writes
Of people neare the Antipodes, call'd Gadlibriens:
Where on the wedding-night the husband hires
Another man to couple with his bride,
To cleare the dangerous passage of a Maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 'Slid he falls backe againe to Mandevile madnesse.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She may be of that Serpentine generation,
That stings oft times to death (as Mandevile writes)

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: She's no Gadlibrien, Sir, upon my knowledge.
You may as safely lodge with her, as with
A mayd of our owne nation. Besides,
You shall have ample counsell: for the present,
Receive her, and intreat her to your Chappell.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: For safety of your Kingdome, you must do it. Haughtboies Exit in state as Letoy directs. Manet Letoy.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: So, so, so, so, this yet may prove a cure.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: See my Lord now is acting by himselfe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And Letoy's wit cryd up triumphant hoe.
Come master Ioylesse and your wife, come downe
Quickly, your parts are next, I had almost
Forgot to send my chaplaine after them.
You Domine where are you?

div.head: Act. 4. Sce. 11.
div.stage: Enter Quailpipe in a fantasticall shape.

sp.speaker: Chap.
sp.l: Tis for my part my Lord,
Which is not all perform'd.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: It is sir, and the Play for this time. We
Have other worke in hand.

sp.speaker: Quai.
sp.l: Then have you lost
Action (I dare be bold to speake it) that
Most of my coat could hardly imitate.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Goe shift your coat sir, or for expedition,
Cover it with your owne, due to your function.
Follyes, as well as vices, may be hid so:
Your vertue is the same; dispatch, and doe
As Doctor Hughball shall direct you, go.
Now Master Ioylesse, doe you note the progresse
And the faire issue likely to insue
In your sons cure? observe the Doctors art.
First, he has shifted your sonnes knowne disease
Of madnesse into folly; and has wrought him
As farre short of a competent reason, as
He was of late beyond it, as a man
Infected by some fowle disease is drawne
By physicke into an Anatomy,
Before flesh fit for health can grow to reare him,
So is a mad-man made a foole, before
Art can take hold of him to wind him up
Into his proper Center, or the Medium
From which he flew beyond himselfe. The Doctor
Assures me now, by what he has collected
As well from learned authors as his practise,
That his much troubled and confused braine
Will by the reall knowledge of a woman,
Now opportunely tane, be by degrees
Setled and rectified, with the helpes beside
Of rest and dyet, which he'le administer.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: But tis the reall knowledge of the woman
(Carnall I think you meane) that carries it.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Nay right or wrong, I could even wish
If he were not my husbands son, the Doctor
Had made my selfe his Recipe, to be the meanes
Of such a Cure.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Perhaps that course might cure your madnes too,
Of jealousy, and set all right on all sides.
Sure, if I could but make him such a foole,
He would forgo his madnes, and be brought
To christian Sence againe.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Heaven grant me patience,
And send us to my Country home againe.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Besides, the yong mans wife's as mad as he,
What wise worke will they make!

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: The better, fear't not,
Bab Blaze shall give her Counsel; and the youth
Will give her royall satisfaction,
Now, in this Kingly humour, I have a way
To cure your husbands jealousy my selfe.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Then I am friends again: Even now I was not
When you sneapt me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: That you must pardon:
Come Mr. Ioylesse. The new married paire
Are towards bed by this time; we'le not trouble them
But keep a house-side to our selfes. Your lodging
Is decently appointed.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Sure your Lordship
Meanes not to make your house our prison.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: By
My Lordship but I will for this one night.
See sir, the Keyes are in my hand. Y'are up,
As I am true Letoy. Consider, Sir,
The strict necessity that tyes you to't,
As you expect a cure upon your sonne—
Come Lady, see your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I doe waite
Upon your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: I both wait, and watch,
Never was man so master'd by his match. Ex. omn.

div.head: Act 5. Scene 1.
div.stage: Ioylesse: with a light in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: DIana! ho! where are you? she is lost.
Here is no further passage. All's made fast.
This was the Bawdy way, by which she scap'd
My narrow watching. Have you privy posternes
Behind the hangings in your strangers Chambers?
She's lost from me, for ever. Why then seek I?
O my dull eyes, to let her slip so from yee,
To let her have her lustfull will upon me!
Is this the Hospitality of Lords?
Why, rather, if he did intend my shame,
And her dishonour, did he not betray me
From her out of his house, to travaile in
The bare suspition of their filthinesse;
But hold me a nose-witnesse to its ranknesse?
No: This is sure the Lordlier way; and makes
The act more glorious in my sufferings. O—
May my hot curses on their melting pleasures,
Cement them so together in their lust,
That they may never part, but grow one monster.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Good gentleman! he is at his prayers now,
For his mad sonnes good night-worke with his bride.
Well fare your heart Sir; you have pray'd to purpose;
But not all night I hope. Yet sure he has,
He looks so wild for lacke of sleepe. Y'are happy sir.
Your prayers are heard, no doubt, for I'm perswaded
You have a childe got you to night.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Is't gone
So farre doe you thinke?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I cannot say how farre.
Not fathome deepe I thinke. But to the scantling
Of a Child-getting, I dare well imagine.
For which, as you have pray'd, forget not sir
To thanke the Lord oth' house.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: For getting me
A child? why I am none of his great Lordships tenants,
Nor of his followers, to keepe his Bastards.
Pray stay a little.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I should goe tell my Lord
The newes: he longs to know how things doe passe.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Tell him I take it well; and thanke him.
I did before despaire of Children I.
But ile goe wi'yee, and thanke him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Sure his joy
Has madded him: Here's more worke for the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: But tell me first: were you their Bawd that speak this?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What meane you with that Dagger?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Nothing I,
But play with't. Did you see the passages
Of things? I aske, were you their Bawd?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Their Bawd?
I trust she is no Bawd, that sees, and helpes
(If need require) an ignorant lawfull paire
To doe their best.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Lords actions all are lawfull.
And how? and how?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: These old folkes love to heare.
Ile tell you sir— and yet I will not neither.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: On? they were off sir yet;
And yet a good while after. They were both
So simple, that they knew not what, not how.
For she's sir, a pure maid.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ile speake no more, lesse you can looke more tamely.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Goe bring me to 'hem then. Bawd will you goe?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ah—

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: What aile you sir: why Bawd? whose Bawd is she?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Your Lords Bawd, and my wives.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: You are jealous mad.
Suppose your wife be missing at your Chamber,
And my Lord too at his, they may be honest:
If not, what's that to her, or you I pray,
Here in my Lords owne house?

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Shee has not seene them. I heard all your talke.
The Child she intimated, is your grandchild
In posse sir, and of your sonnes begetting.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I, ile be sworne I meant, and said so too?

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: I can give no account,
If she be with my Lord I dare not trouble hem.
Nor must you offer at it: no nor stab your selfe. Byp. takes away his dagger.
But come with me: we counsell, or, at least,
Governe you better: Shee may be, perhaps,
About the Bride-chamber, to heare some sport;
For you can make her none; 'lasse good old man.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Vnlesse
The killing of your selfe may do't; and that
J would forbeare, because perhaps 'twould please her.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Jf fire, or water, poyson, cord, or steele,
Or any meanes be found to do it: ile doe it;
Not to please her, but rid me of my torment. Ex. Joy, and Byp.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: J have more care and charge of you than so.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What an old desperate man is this, to make
Away your selfe for feare of being a Cuckold!
If every man that is, or that but knowes
Himselfe to be oth' order, should doe so,
How many desolate widowes would here be,
They are not all of that minde. Here's my husband.

div.head: Act 5. Scene 4.
div.stage: Ent. Blaze with a habit in his hand.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Looke well. How thinkst thou Tony?
Hast not thou neither slept to night?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Yes, yes.
I lay with the Butler. Who was thy bed-fellow?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You know I was appoynted to sit up.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Yes, with the Doctor in the Bride-chamber.
But had you two no waggery? Ha!

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Nay facks I am not jealous:
Thou knowst I was cur'd long since, and how.
I jealous! I an asse. A man sha' n't aske
His wife shortly, how such a gentleman does?
Or how such a gentleman did? or which did best?
But she must thinke him jealous.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You need not: for
If I were now to dye on't, nor the Doctor,
Nor I came in a bed to night: I meane
Within a bed.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Within, or without, or over, or under,
I have no time to thinke o' such poore things.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: O ho Bab.
This is a shape.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: A shape? what shape I prethee Tony?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Thou'lt see me in't anon; but shalt not know me
From the starkst foole ith' Towne. And I must dance
Naked in't Bab.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Yes Bab. My Lord gave order for't last night.
It should ha' bin ith' Play: But because that
Was broke off, he will ha't today.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O Tony.
I did not see thee act ith' Play.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: O, but
I did though Bab, two Mutes.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Fie foole, thou understandst not what a Mute is.
A Mute is a dumbe Speaker in the Play.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Dumbe Speaker! that's a Bull. Thou wert the Bull
Then, in the Play. Would I had seene thee rore.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: That's a Bull too, as wise as you are Bab.
A Mute is one that acteth speakingly,
And yet sayes nothing. I did two of them.
The Sage Man-midwife, and the Basket-maker.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Well Tony, I will see thee in this thing.
And tis a pretty thing.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Prethee good Bab,
Come in, and help me on with't in our Tyring-house.
And helpe the Gentlemen, my fellow dancers,
And thou shalt then see all our things, and all
Our properties and practice to the Musicke.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: O Tony come, I long to be at that. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: My Lord, your strength and violence prevaile not.
There is a Providence above my vertue,
That guards me from the fury of your lust.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yet, yet, I prethee yield. Is it my person
That thou despisest? See, here's wealthy treasure, a table set forth, covered with treasure.
Jewells, that Cleopatra would have left
Her Marcus for.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: My Lord tis possible,
That she who leaves a husband, may be bought
Out of a second friendship.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Had stout Tarquin
Made such an offer, he had done no Rape,
For Lucrece had consented, sav'd her owne,
And all those lives that followed in her cause.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Yet then she had beene a loser.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Wouldst have gold?
Mammon, nor Pluto's selfe should over-bid me,
For il'd give all. First, let me raine a showre,
To out-vie that which overwhelmed Danae;
And after that another; a full river
Shall from my chests perpetually flow
Into thy store.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I have not much lov'd wealth,
But have not loath'd the sight of it, till now,
That you have soyld it with that foule opinion
Of being the price of vertue. Though the Metall
Be pure, and innocent in it selfe; such use
Of it is odious, indeed damnable,
Both to the seller, and the purchaser:
Pitty it should be so abus'd. It beares
A stampe upon't, which but to clip is treason.
Tis ill us'd there, where Law the life controules;
Worse, where tis made a salary for soules.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Deny'st thou wealth? wilt thou have pleasure then
Given, and ta'ne freely, without all condition?
Ile give thee such, as shall (if not exceed)
Be at the least, comparative with those,
Which Iupiter got the Demy-gods with; and
Iuno was mad she mist.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: My Lord, you may
Glose o're and gild the vice, which you call pleasure,
With god like attributes; when it is, at best
A sensuality, so farre below
Dishonourable, that it is meere beastly;
Which reason ought to abhorre; and I detest it,
More than your former hated offers.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Lastly.
Wilt thou have honour! Ile come closer to thee;
(For now the Flames of Love grow higher in me,
And I must perish in them, or enjoy thee)
Suppose I finde by Power, or Law, or both,
A meanes to make thee mine, by freeing
Thee from thy present husband.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Hold, stay there.
Now should I utter volumes of perswasions;
Lay the whole world of Riches, pleasures, honours,
Before me in full grant, that one, last word
Husband, and from your owne mouth spoke, confutes
And vilifies even all. The very name
Of husband, rightly weigh'd, and well remembred,
Without more Law or discipline, is enough
To governe woman-kinde in due obedience;
Master all loose affections, and remove
Those Idolls, which too much, too many love;
And you have set before me, to beguile
Me of the faith I owe him. But, remember
You grant I have a husband; urge no more,
I seek his love. Tis fit he loves no whore.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: This is not yet the way. You have seene Lady,
My ardent love, which you doe seeme to slight,
Though to my death, pretending zeale to your husband.
My person, nor my proffers are so despicable,
But that they might (had I not vow'd affection
Intirely to your selfe) have met with th'embraces
Of greater persons, no lesse faire, that can
Too, (if they please) put on Formality,
And talke in as divine a straine, as you.
This is not earnest, make my word but good,
Now with a smile, ile give thee a thousand pound.
Looke o' my face— Come— prithee looke and laugh not—
Yes, laugh, and dar'st— Dimple this cheek a little;
Ile nip it else.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I pray forbeare my Lord:
I'me past a childe, and will be made no wanton.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: How can this be? so young? so vigorous?
And so devoted to an old mans bed!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That is already answerd. He's my husband.
You are old too my Lord.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes, but of better metall:
A jealous old man too, whose disposition
Of injury to beauty, and young blood,
Cannot but kindle fire of just revenge
In you, if you be woman, to requite
With your owne pleasure his unnaturall spight.
You cannot be worse to him than he thinkes you,
Considering all the open scornes and jeeres
You cast upon him, to a flat defiance;
Then the affronts I gave, to choake his anger:
And lastly your stolne absence from his chamber:
All which confirmes (we have as good as told him)
That he's a Cuckold, yet you trifle time,
As 'twere not worth the doing.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Are you a Lord?
Dare you boast honor, and be so ignoble?
Did not you warrant me upon that pawne
(Which can take up no mony) your blanck honour,
That you would cure his jealousie, which affects him
Like a sharpe sore, if I to ripen it
Would set that counterfeit face of scorne upon him,
Onely in shew of disobedience, which
You wonne me to, upon your protestation,
To render me unstain'd to his opinion,
And quit me of his jealousie for ever.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: No: not unstain'd by your leave, if you call
Unchastity a staine. But for his yellows,
Let me but lye with you, and let him know it,
His jealousie is gone, all doubts are cleard,
And for his love and good opinion,
He shall not dare deny't. Come; be wise,
And this is all: all is as good as done
To him already: let't be so with us;
And trust to me, my power, and your owne,
To make all good with him— If not: Now marke,
To be revengd for my lost hopes (which yet
I pray thee save) Ile put thee in his hands,
Now in his heat of fury; and not spare
To boast thou art my Prostitute; and thrust yee
Out of my gates, to try't out by your selves.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: this you may doe, and yet be still a Lord;
This can I beare, and still be the same woman!
I am not troubled now, your wooing oratory,
Your violent hands (made stronger by your lust)
Your tempting gifts, and larger promises
Of honor and advancements were all frivolous;
But this last way of threats, ridiculous,
To a safe minde, that beares no guilty grudge:
My peace dwells here, while yonder sits my judge.
And in that faith ile dye.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: She is invincible!
Come ile relate you to your husband.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: No,
Ile meet her with more joy then I receiv'd
Upon our marriage-day. My better soule.
Let me againe embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Take your dudgeon Sir,
I ha done you simple service.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: O my Lord,
My Lord, you have cur'd my jealousie, I thanke you;
And more, your man for the discovery;
But most the constant meanes, my vertuous wife,
Your medicine my sweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: she has tane all
I meane to give her sir Now sirrah, speake.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: I brought you to the stand from whence you saw
How the game went.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: I seemd to doe it against my will, by which I gain'd
Your bribe of twenty peeces.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: But I assure you, my Lord give me order,
To place you there, after it seemes he had
Well put her to't within.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Stay, stay, stay, stay;
Why may not this be then a counterfeit action,
Or a false mist to blinde me with more error?
The ill I fear'd may have beene done before,
And all this but deceit to dawbe it ore.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: I must take charge I see o'th' dagger againe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Come Ioylesse, I have pitty on thee; Heare me.
I swear upon mine honor she is chast.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I prithee Heare me.
I try'd and tempted her for mine owne ends,
More then for thine.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And had she yielded, I not onely had
Rejected her (for it was ne're my purpose,
(Heaven I call thee to witnesse) to commit
A sinne with her) but layd a punishment
Upon her, greater then thou couldst inflict.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Doe you know your father Lady?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I hope I am so wise a childe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Goe call
In my friend Truelocke,

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Take your dagger Sir,
Now I dare trust you.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Sirrah, dare you foole.
When I am serious? send in master Truelocke. Exit Byp.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Sir, I am neither conjurer nor witch,
But a great Fortune-teller, that youl finde,
You are happy in a wife sir, happier— yes
Happier by a hundred thousand pound,
Then you were yesterday—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I meane in possibilities: provided that
You use her well, and never more be jealous.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Looke you this way sir,
When I speake to you, ile crosse your fortune else,
As I am true Letoy.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Mad, mad, he's mad,
Would we were quickly out on's fingers yet.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: When saw you your wives father? answer me?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: He came for London foure dayes before us.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Tis possible he's here then, doe you know him

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: O I am happy in his sight. Deare sir. Enter Truelocke. she kneeles.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Tis but so much knee-labour lost, stand up,
Stand up, and minde me.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: You are well met, sonne Ioylesse.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: How have you beene conceald, and this house?
Here's mystery in this.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: know sir, that J sent for him, and for you,
Jnstructing your friend Blaze my instrument,
To draw you to my Doctor with your sonne,
Your wife J knew must follow, what my end
Was in't shall quickely be discover'd to you,
In a few words, of your supposed father.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes, come master Truelocke,
My constant friend of thirty yeares acquaintance,
Freely declare with your best knowledge now,
Whose childe this is.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Your honor do's as freely
Release me of my vow, then in the secret
I lockd up in this brest these seaventeene yeares
Since she was three dayes old.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: True, master Truelocke,
I doe release you of your vow: Now speake.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Now she is yours my Lord; your onely daughter,
And know you master Ioylesse, for some reason
Knowne to my Lord; and large reward to me,
Shee has beene from the third day of her life
Reputed mine; and that so covertly,
That not her Lady mother, nor my wife
Knew to their deaths, the change of my dead infant,
Nor this sweet Lady. tis most true we had
A trusty Nurses helpe and secresie,
Well paid for, in the carriage of our plot.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Now shall you know what mov'd me sir. I was
A thing beyond a mad-man, like your selfe,
Jealous; and had that strong distrust, and fancied
Such proofes unto my selfe against my wife,
That I conceiv'd the childe was not mine owne,
And scorn'd to father it; yet I gave to breed her
And marry her as the daughter of this gentleman
(Two thousand pound I guesse you had with her)
But since your match, my wife upon her death-bed,
So clear'd her selfe of all my foule suspitions,
(Blest be her memory) that J then resolv'd
By some quaint way (for J am still Letoy)
To see and try her throughly; and so much
To make her mine, as I should find her worthy.
And now thou art my daughter, and mine heire.
Provided still (for I am still Letoy)
You honourably love her, and defie
The Cuckold-making fiend foule jealousie.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: My Lord, tis not her birth and fortune, which
Do joyntly claime a priviledge to live
Above my reach of jealousie, shall restraine
That passion in me, but her well tried vertue:
Jn the true faith of which J am confirmd,
And throughly cur'd.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: As J am true Letoy
Well said. J hope thy son is cur'd by this too.
Now Mistris Blaze! here is a woman now!
J cur'd her husbands jealousie, and twenty more
jth' Towne, by meanes I and my Doctor wrought.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Truly my Lord, my husband has tane bread
And drunke upon't, that under heaven he thinkes,
You were the meanes to make me an honest woman,
Or (at the least) him a contented man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes, I beleeve you have done
And if your husband, Lady, be cur'd, as he should be;
And as all foolish jealous husbands ought to be,
I know what was done first, if my Lord tooke
That course with you as me—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My Lord to tell you, (As the Doctor tels me)
The Bride and Bridegroome, Both, are comming on,
The sweetliest to their wits againe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Now you are a happy man sir; and I hope a quiet man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Content! So was my husband, when he knew
The worst he could by his wife. Now youle live quiet Lady.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Why flyest thou off, thus woman, from the subject
Thou wert upon?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I beg your Honours pardon.
And now ile tell you. Be it by skill or chance,
Or both, was never such a Cure, as is
Vpon that couple: now they strive which most
Shall love the other.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Vp! up, and ready to lye downe againe:
There is no ho with them;
They have bin in th' Antipodes to some purpose;
And, now, are risen, and return'd themselves:
he's her deare Per, and she is his sweet Mat.
His Kingship and her Queenship are forgotten.
And all their melancholly and his Travailes past,
And but suppos'd their dreams.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now sir, the Doctor, (for he is become
An utter stranger to your sonne; and so
Are all about em) craves your presence,
And such as he's acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Go sir.
And go you daughter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Daughter! that's the true trick of all old whore-masters, to call their wenches daughters.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Has he knowne you friend Trulock too?

sp.speaker: Let
sp.p: Go, then, and possesse him (Now, he is sensible) how things have gone; what Arte, what meanes, what friends have bin imploy'd in his rare cure; and win him, by degrees, to Sense of where he is; bring him to me; and I have yet an entertainment for him, Of better Settle-braine, then Drunkards porridge, To set him right. As I am true Letoy, I have one Toy left. Go, and go you, why stayst thou? Exe. Ioy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: If I had beene a Gentle-woman borne,
I should have bin your daughter too my Lord.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: But never as she is.
You'le know anon.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Neat city-wives flesh, yet may be as good,
As your course countrey gentlewomans blood. Exit Bar.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Goe with thy flesh to Turn-bull shambles? Hoe
Within there.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: The musicke, songs,
And dance I gave command for, are they ready?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: All my good Lord: and (in good sooth) I cannot enough applaude your honours quaint conceit in the designe; so apt, so regular, so pregnant, so acute, and so (withall) poetice legitimate, as I may say justly with Plautus—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Prithee say no more, but see upon my signall given, they act as well as I design'd.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Nay not so well my exact Lord, but as they may, they shall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I know no flatterer in my house but this,
But for his custome I must beare with him.
'Sprecious they come already. Now beginne.

div.head: Act 5. Sce. 9.
div.stage: A solemne lesson upon the Recorders. Ent. Truelocke, Ioylesse and Diana, Peregrine and Martha, Doctor, and Barbara, Letoy meets them. Truelocke presents Peregrine and Martha to him, he salutes them. They seeme to make some short discourse. Then Letoy appoints them to sit Peregrine seemes somthing amazed. The Musicke ceases.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Againe you are welcome sir and welcome all.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am what you are pleas'd to make me; but withall, so ignorant of mine owne condition; whether I sleepe, or wake, or talke, or dreame; whether I be, or be not; or if I am, whether I doe, or doe not any thing: for I have had (if I now wake) such dreames, and been so far transported in a long and tedious voyage of sleep, that I may fear my manners can acquire no welcome, where men understand themselves.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: This is Musick, Sir, you are welcome; and I give full power Unto your father, and my daughter here, your mother to make you welcome. Ioylesse whispers Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: My Lord you'l put him backe againe, if you trouble his braine with new discoveries.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Fetch him you on againe then: pray are you Letoy or I?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I feare your show will but perplex him too.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I care not sir, ile have it to delay your cure a while, that he recover soundly. Come sit again, again you are most welcome.

div.head: Act 5. Sce. 10.
div.stage: A most untunable florish. Ent. Discord attended by Folly, Iealousie, Melancholy and madnesse.

sp.p: There's an unwelcome guest; uncivill Discord that traines into my house her followers, Folly, and Jealousie, Melancholy, and madnesse.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: My husband presents jealousie in the black and yellow jaundied sute there, halfe like man, and tother halfe like woman with one horne, and asse-eare upon his head.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Peace woman, marke what they doe: but but by the way, conceive me this, but shew sir, and devise.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: How goes he backe againe, now doctor? sheugh.

lg.head: Discord. Song in untunable notes.
lg.l: COme forth my darlings, you that breed
The common strifes that discord feed:
Come in the first place, my deare folly;
Iealousie next, then Melancholy.
And last come Madnesse, thou art hee
That bearst th' effects of all those three,
Lend me your aydes, so discord shake you crowne,
And make this place a kingdome of our owne.

div.head: Act 5. Scene 11.
div.stage: They dance. After a while they are broke off by a flourish, and the approach of Harmony followed by Mercury, Cupid, Bacchus and Apollo. Discord and her faction fall downe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: See Harmony approaches, leading on,
Gainst Discords factions feare great deities;
Mercury, Cupid, Bacchus, and Apollo.
Wit against Folly, Love against Jealousie,
Wine against Melancholly, and gainst Madnesse, Health.
Observe the matter and the Method.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And how upon the approach of Harmony,
Discord and her disorders are confounded.

lg.head: Harmony. Song.
lg.l: COme Wit, come Love, come Wine, come Health,
Mayntainers of my Common-wealth,
Tis you make Harmony compleate,
And from the Spheares (her proper seate)
You give her power to raigne on earth,
Where Discord claimes a right by birth.
Then let us revell it while we are here,
And keepe possession of this Hemisphere.

div.stage: After a straine or two, Discord cheares up her faction. They all rise, and mingle in the dance with Harmony and the rest. Daunce.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Note there how Discord cheares up her disorders,
To mingle in defiance with the Vertues:
But soone they vanish; and the mansion quit Ex Discord.
Unto the Gods of health, love, wine and wit,
Who triumph in their habitation new,
Which they have taken, and assigne to you;
In which they now salute you— Bids you bee Salute Exe.
Of cheare; and for it, layes the charge on me.
And unto me y'are welcome, welcome all.
Meat, wine, and mirth shall flow, and what I see,
Yet wanting in your cure, supplied shall be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And so shall I,
After a few such nights more.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Are you there?
Good Madam, pardon errors of my tongue.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I am too happy made to thinke of wrong.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: We will want nothing for you that may please,
Though we dive for it toth' Antipodes.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: WHether my cure be perfect yet or no,
It lies not in my doctor-ship to know.
Your approbation may more raise the man,
Then all the Colledge of physitians can;
And more health from your faire hands may be wonne,
Then by the streakings of the seaventh sonne.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And from our Travailes in th' Antipodes.
We are not yet arriv'd from off the Seas:
But on the waves of desprate feares we roame
Vntill your gentler hands doe waft us home.

div.p: You shal find in this Booke more then was presented upon the Stage, and left out of the Presentation, for superfluous length (as some of the Players pretended) I thoght good al should be inserted according to the allowed Original; and as it was, at first, intended for the Cock-pit Stage, in the right of my most deserving Friend Mr. William Beeston, unto whom it properly appertained; and so J leave it to thy perusal, as it was generally applauded, and well acted at Salisbury Court.
